Buddy Program  
   11-Oct-21 Soliton Technologies Confidential  2

What is Buddy Program?  
The Buddy Program matches new  
joinees  
with Solitons, who have been with the company  
for some time (typically 12  
- 
18 
 months),  
for a period of six months with two primary goals.  
1. 
To provide the new  
joinee  
with a point of contact for general queries and help him/her to  
settle  
. 
2. 
To help the new  
joinee  
integrate with the company by providing access to someone who  
is familiar with Soliton culture, values and principles that guide our  
behaviour  
.  11-Oct-21 Soliton Technologies Confidential  3

Advantages  
By providing such a relationship, it is intended that:  
• 
The new  
joinee  
will feel more at home with the company, in a shorter period  
• 
Relatively straightforward queries regarding basic operational issues are dealt with in a  
timely manner  
• 
Manager’s / supervisor’s time with new  
joinee  
s 
is freed up to deal with more critical or  
urgent matters  
• 
The initial confusion and uncertainty faced by all new  
joinees  
is lessened  
• 
The new  
joinee  
begins to add value quickly, leading to increased confidence   11-Oct-21 Soliton Technologies Confidential  4

Role of a buddy  
A buddy typically takes on the following tasks to help the new  
joinee  
settle in:  
• Be available to answer immediate routine questions of a general nature, day  
- 
to 
- 
day  
operational information, such as the location of facilities, information requirements and  
relevant company policies etc.  
• Provide information on how the Team or Project operates, project specific policies and  
procedures, and other sources of infor mation.

What does a Buddy not do?  
A buddy should not involve themselves in issues relating to the new member’s performance

expectations and standards, training, etc.   11-Oct-21 Soliton Technologies Confidential  5 Selection & pairing of buddies  
Solitons who have been with the company for some time (typically 12 -18 months) are nominated 
by Project/ Team Managers based on the following criteria:  
• Has good communication and interpersonal skills  
• Has the willingness to help others  
• Has the time and ban dwidth to be accessible to the new joinee  
• Is at a peer level to the new joinee  
• Has good knowledge of our company, and is committed to Soliton's vision and values  
Recruitment team will ask the Project managers to nominate the person at the time of hiring 
confirmation. PMs can nominate them directly or ask for volunteers within their team.   11-Oct-21 Soliton Technologies Confidential  6 
The Buddy will be briefed about the role and responsibilities by the Recruitment team, and then 
introduced to the new joinee . The team will take feedback from the new joi nee, at the end of 6 
months, on the overall experience and the support and knowledge received from the Buddy.

Business Travel Policy  
This travel policy serves as a guideline for Solitons to understand the general practices and norms that 
could be followed and not to be used as a rule book.  
Solitons can apply their best judgement to make effective decisions that satisfy business and personal 
needs and use this freedom with responsibility.  
The following are the allowances which we can avail during official travel:  
• Food Allowance [outside bas e location]  
• Travel Allowance [outside base location]  
• Accommodation Allowance [outside base location]  
• Local Commuting Allowance [local travel within non -base location for official purpose, and local 
travel within the base location for official purpose ot her than commute to office]

Food Allowance   
It is an allowance given to cover the food expenses during the business trip. The allowance is computed 
based on the cost of living.   
Solitons are eligible for food allowance as mentioned below  
• Tier 1 cities (Bangalore, Mumbai & Delhi) – Rs.700/ -  
• Tier 2 (Chennai & Hyderabad) – Rs.600/ -  
• Other citi es – Rs.500/-

Travel Reimbursement   
a) For an overnight journey, it is recommended to travel in train or bus depending on our  
  convenience. Train travel is recommended since it is safer.  
b) We can take the help of the Admin team to book the tickets. Please inform the travel desk,  
  preferably at least 3 weeks in advance for booking tickets.  
c) Solitons are eligible for travel reimbursement up to 3 tier a/c fare or equivalent.  
d) Up to Sr. Lead – 3 tier A/c fare or equivalent amount  
e) Manager & above – Flight or equivalent amount  
f) Local commuting allowance – On actuals

PLEASE NOTE:   
a) Air travel will be sanctioned by the Managers as demanded by the circumstances for  
  medical emergencies, urgent travel, etc.  
b) As a general principle, we are encouraged to communicate any inconvenience we may face,   
   to our Team Lead or Manager so that a ppropriate arrangements can be made.  
c) Travel Reimbursement will not be applicable for offsite Training Programs happening in Coimbatore 
for whom the base / work location is Coimbatore (as per offer letter). Any travel from Coimbatore 
to the training location will still be reimbursed as per the training policy. Those who are not sure of 
their base location can refer to this < https://solitontech.sharepoint.com/:x:/s/thepeopleteam/EZ -
HC5AD5GdNo4be3CC8jHIB_Qw409pw4pYhnU00y6G13Q?e=RpGHBk&wdLOR=cD402DDB2 -
2974 -4104 -8231 -7A9807BA491B   >  to clarify it.

Accommodation Allowance   
Solitons will be provided with a safe, clean, and convenient hotel to stay in when traveling.  
a) We can avail the recommended hotels list in various cities from the Admin team and request  booking 
assis tance.  
b) When traveling to a new city where we do not have a recommended hotel, we are authorized  
  to find a suitable hotel based on the rate guidelines  from the Admin Team.  
c) The rate guidelines will be based on the prevailing rates at recommended hotels.   
d) We are encouraged to provide information to the Admin Team about the quality of the accommodation 
(good or bad) so that the recommended hotel list can be updated with the information from the most 
recent trip.  
The following is the rate guidelines (inc luding GST) for Coimbatore, Bangalore & Chennai based on the 
prevailing rates.  
• Coimbatore – Rs.2000/ - per day  
• Bangalore – Rs.3000/ - per day  
• Chennai – Rs.3000/ - per day  
The list of city wise recommended hotels is available with the admin team. Any hotel in the similar price 
range is approved

Local Commuting Allowance   
a) When traveling within the city on company business, we may use our own vehicle and claim 
reimbursement at the rate of Rs.4.00/km for two wheelers by submitting a reimbursement claim  
  form to the Accounts team authorized by the Team Manager.  
b) Alternativel y, we may use an auto or a taxi and get reimbursement.  
c) Solitons are requested to give due attention to safety when traveling to remote locations and late 
hours. Please discuss work plans with the Project Managers and get the necessary authorizations,  
in advance.  
d) We do not want anybody to put themselves in a dangerous situation under any circumstances. 
Solitons are authorized to do what we feel is safe and update our Team Lead the next day and 
apply for reimbursement if applicable.   
e) Reimbursement can be claimed on actuals on receipt of bills.

Note :  
a) All the above rates will be reviewed periodically and updated. If at any time the actual expense exceeds 
this amount due to circumstances that we could not avoid without a lot of incon venience, we are 
requested to explain this to the Project Manager and get the authorization for the higher reimbursement.  
b) If we are in a situation where, despite our best efforts, we are not able to contact the appropriate person 
to authorize an excepti on from policy, we are free to make the decision ourselves and the company will 
cover the expenses.  
c) The basic principle is that our policies should not compromise anybody’s safety under any 
circumstances or cause undue inconvenience.

Onsite Allowan ce:  
Onsite allowance is paid for engineers deployed at the customer site for a specified project duration 
exceeding 15 days. Onsite allowance is paid to support a Soliton in terms of accommodation, food, and 
travel. For Onsite outside India per diem will be applicable.  
Per Diem: That means a certain amount per day which will be paid to us on a weekly, biweekly, or monthly 
basis. In addition to this our Indian salary will continue to be credited to our bank account.  
For all official travel, Solitons are requested to discuss with their Project Managers and request the Travel 
Desk to provide the necessary travel advance to cover the trip expenses. The advance has to be settled 
within a week after returning from the trip .  
Travel Desk: Contact - admin.support@solitontech.com

Feedback Channels    
We foster a culture that encourages open and honest communication across all levels (Peer to Peer, Team member 
to Reporting manager, Solitons to Leadership team, Juniors to Seniors etc). Soliton welcomes all types of feedback 
(general comments, compliments , constructive criticism, and concerns).  
Ultimately, the aim is to share all observations in a constructive way that helps engage others, encourage Solitons 
to listen to each other’s ideas and solve problems together in a way that drives continuous improv ement.  
These guidelines are created to set forth different channels by which all Solitons can effectively voice their 
feedback.

Guidelines    
Solitons can make use of the following channels for providing feedback;  
1. Direct (verbal / email):  
This is the most recommended channel for all types of feedback.  
We encourage the leaders to use this channel to give effective feedback to their team members. Team members 
can use this platform to provide feedback to their reporting manager, and it can al so be used among non -reporting 
colleagues as well.   
2. Through a mediator (email):  
In the event where Solitons are not able to share their feedback about their peers / colleagues / seniors / 
juniors / Reporting Manager directly, they can route it through a mediator. Solitons can also use this channel to 
share reviews about any Soliton that includes HR team members and Leadership team.  
Such feedback can be sent to feedback@solitontech.com  and it will be routed to HR Manager (Anu Antony) and 
Leadership team  members (Ganesh Devaraj & Arjun Sathiyaseelan) who will help to mediate the discussion. 
Solitons can feel free to write email directly to any of the leadership team members as well.  
3. Anonymous channel (written):  
Solitons can make use of this channel by filling -in the details of their feedback using this  <

Guidelines    
https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=6HLtBhmklUees1USzx09mFbIMP5zgT9Nqd%20cLyo9tj
21UN1A4T0RXS0hURUVPMlhVTUtQRVlMVE5SRy4u&wdLOR=cA8FC45E5 -002F -4607 -A73B -B2803E9FEFC1  > 
link.   
Since this channel does not directly align with our culture of openness, we don’t recomme nd using this 
channel in a normal scenario. But incase if any Soliton feels uncomfortable in disclosing his or her identity 
while sharing the feedback especially about those who are in senior roles, this channel can be used.  
 You need to be aware that anonymity can be helpful for bringing an issue to light, but it may not help to 
understand the issue and solve it. Anonymous feedback takes away the opportunity for people to talk things 
through so that they can find ways to work better together in the future.  
If any Soliton wants to address the feedback through a formal channel involving Human Resources, until closure, 
you can send it through the Grievance redressing channel (refer grievance redressal policy for more details).

How to give an effective feedback?    
Feedback should be given in a manner that will best help improve performance. Since people respond better to 
information presented in a positive way, feedback should be expressed with the intent to help the pers on. . This is 
not to say that information should be sugar -coated. It must be accurate, factual, and complete.  
Here are some guidelines to ensure that the feedback is constructive that your colleagues are more likely to accept;  
Feedback Formula = Situati on + Behaviour + Impact + Next step  
• Situation:  
Specify the situation on which you give your feedback. It is important to give your colleague a context with the 
point of time and date to relate to. Let him/her know that you are referring to what happened during the team 
meeting a day before (not the pre sentation three weeks ago, for example).  
• Behaviour  
- Describe the behaviour. Make sure that you are being clear and objective. Focus on the actions   that your 
colleague took, not his / her personality.  
• Impact:  
You can make your feedback stronger by de scribing the impact of the - demonstrated behaviour. For instance, your 
colleague’s action - could impact one person, a few people or the whole group. Think of the big picture and choose 
the impact that is most appropriate in each situation.  
• The Next Step :  
Finally, offer your colleague the next steps that he/she can take. Suggest what he / she could do, to - handle it better 
next time.

Take Care of Your Body Language  
When you give your feedback in person, be aware of your body language. Avoid gestur es or a tone that might either 
send recipients into a defensive mode or make them afraid - - Don’t raise your voice. It might seem like you are 
angry. Instead, just share the critical comments and help them understand how they can improve. You are not angr y, 
you just say all these critical comments to help them improve.   
 - Don’t cross your arms. You don’t want to look like you are not going to let them explain their 
behaviour.  
- Don’t frown. You are not there to judge but to provi de support.  
- Keep a friendly t one and an open body because you want to create a atmosphere of trust and 
openness. That would really help the recipient to take in your feedback.

How to receive feedback effectively?    
1. Be an active listener. Practice your effective listening skills. Encourage the person offering feedback to 
talk. You will learn more about yourself, how others see you, and how others interpret your actions and 
behaviors.   
2. Be respectful. Be aware of your body language, facial expression, and tone. Maintain eye contact and be 
careful not to get defensive (not even crossing your arms). If you disagree, are upset, or angry, give yourself 
time to calm down before responding. And, when you do, carefully choose your words; they matter. Take it 
for what it is; that is, feedback you can use to improve your performance. Think on how you can improve 
the behavior, attitude, or situation. Learn from it.   
3. Ask questions. Clarify doubts by asking questi ons. Be certain to ask questions that help you to 
understand the feedback. Ask for examples that support the feedback.   
4. Show appreciation. Express your appreciation regardless of the type of feedback you receive. You can 
expect that at several times duri ng employment, you will receive both positive and negative feedback. 
Saying thank you means that you acknowledge the effort that was taken to provide feedback.   
5. Make a decision. Reflect on the feedback and decide your next steps, how are going to use the feedback 
to further your development. You don’t always have to act on all the feedback that you receive. You build 
your relationship with someone when they feel heard, which is ac hieved by you listening, without 
judgement. We would r ecommend, that you reinforce the value you place on their feedback by circling 
back around and letting them know what you ultimately did.

Processing Feedback    
Once feedback has been received  through the 2nd and 3rd channels, it will be assessed for further action.  
If the feedback is a general comment, compliment, concern or constructive criticism, it will be communicated 
immediately to the person involved. If the matter requires greater atte ntion, and has some level of complication, it 
will be further discussed at different levels and communicated to the person involved along with 
advice/recommendation on the appropriate course of action.

Flexi -pay Benefit Plan – Questions & Clarifications summary as on 27 -April -21, 5PM   
Q1: For meal vouchers, if I have some balance in ICICI Multi -wallet card by end of the FY , I would 
be able to use next FY . Is this the same case for fuel and mobile part added to ICICI Multi -wallet?  
What will be my taxable amount if I spend only partial amount of money that was loaded on fuel 
and mobile part of ICICI Multi -wallet card by end of FY?  
The amount loaded in the multi -wallet card is already tax exempted and it is up to us how and 
when we use it. The remaining amount can be used in the next Financial year as well. You can use 
the accumulated balance until the expiry of the card. The card is valid for 5 years. And, it is the 
same for the fuel and mobile balance as well; it is available until the expiry of the card.

Q2: When we had Sodexo we were able to purchase grocery items using it, Is this applicable 
for ICICI Multi -wallet card?  
Yes, you can use the ICICI multi -wallet card to purchase groceries.   
Q3: If we didn't opt for Multi -wallet or meal card can we submit Bills as proof and claim the same? 
This is because I have heard many grocery stores are not a ccepting meal cards and only 
restaurants are accepting it.  
Only petrol and vehicle maintenance, phone bills can be submitted, not grocery/food bills.  
Is this a restriction from Soliton Or from IT department ? 
It is not a restriction from Soliton; this is regulation followed by corporates - Sodexo and meal 
cards are accepted, but bills are not.

Q4: If we are to claim petrol allowance without using the ICICI Multi -wallet card, is producing 
either of the debit/credit card transaction slip or written bill as proof good enough?  
Yes, you must submit the debit/credit transaction slip and the original bill. Please take a xerox 
copy as the slip usually fades away within a few we eks.  
Q5: Can the ICICI meal card be used in all grocery shops or only in selected shops?  
A: If they have a swipe machine, they would have registered as a grocery shop and can take the 
card.  
Q6: Only online transactions for Fuel are valid is it? Beca use of COVID I am not using Card 
anywhere  
 Yes, you can use the ICICI multi -wallet card in online transactions as well.   
Q7: For fuel can we pay using cash and claim with bill?  
Yes, we can

Q8: The vehicles at home are registered in my Parents' name and I use them only for my 
commute. The guideline says that RC Book should be in my name. Then, with this case, I guess I 
cannot claim this component. Could you confirm?  
A : Yes, the vehicle has to  be registered in your name to claim this component

Q9: Until office opens, we would not be able to claim vehicle allowance, right?  
We can claim vehicle allowance. Even though we are all working from home, as long as we have 
the bills, we can claim it. Govt. has not made any restrictions on it. Moreover, we all will be 
incurring the maintenance expenses and those bills also can be claimed.

Q9: Please share your thoughts on this Scenario below,  
One person is opting for the maximum limit  (₹12,000) in one section of FBP (say Professional  
Development  Bills  Reimbursement  of  ₹12,000)    
 End of the Year when the Proof Submission comes and the person was able to produce proof for 
only ₹8000   
 What’s  the  result  in  that  person’s  tax  structure?   
1. Will ₹8,000 be tax exempted and ₹4000(₹12,000 -₹8,000=₹4,000) be added to the taxable 
income?   
 (or)   
2. Will  ₹12,000  be  still  tax  exempted?  (not  reasonable  but 
 still  good   )  
 (or)  
3. Will ₹12,000 as a whole be added to taxable income as the bills were insufficient ?  
Replies for the above 3 questions :   
1. Yes   
2. Only 8000 is tax exempted - whatever you submit as proofs will be exempt of tax, the remaining 
portion is taxed.   
3. Let us get back to you as it will involve some back -end process.

Questions to be clarified :  
1). Are the Flexi Pay Benefits (FPB) deductions applicable for both old tax regime and new tax regime? 
(or) only applicable for old tax regime?   
2). Any restrictions on the nature of mobile/telephone connection - prepaid/postpaid - for claiming 
tax exempti on?  
3). If I opt for adding Vehicle allowance to ICICI card (Rs 2400/mo), and have RC only for a 2 wheeler 
(Rs 900/mo), what amount will be added to the card and what amount will be tax -deductible?

Grievance Redressal Policy  
Soliton is committed to providing a fair, safe, and productive work environment where grievances are dealt 
sensitively and expeditiously.   
We recognize that workplace challenges may arise from time to time and have found that the best way of 
maintaining job satisfaction and good working relationship, is to follow a procedure for solving problems 
and grievances.   
The objective of the Griev ance Redressal Policy is to settle grievances of Solitons at the shortest possible 
time and to provide a process so that the Soliton seeking redressal derives satisfaction.

Scope    
A grievance may be about any act, omission, situation, or decision that a Soliton thinks is unfair, 
discriminatory, or unjustified.   
For example, We could have a grievance about:   
a. working hours or leaves    
b. work environment   
c. safety in the workplace    
d. salary levels   
e. nature of supervision    
f. performance appraisal    
g. transfer or promotion   
h. skill development or training    
i. discrimination or harassment   
The examples mentioned above are only indicative and not exhaustive.   
Disqualification:    
All grievances related to sexual harassment at workplace will be covered under ‘Prevention of Sexual 
Harassment Policy’ and is excluded from the purview of this policy .

Guideline    
Formal (Open door policy)   
Solitons are free to meet any one from the leadership team including Ganesh Devaraj and Arjun 
Sathiyaseelan. But for the purpose of tracking and following it up until closure, it is recommended to route 
it to the People Manag er. 
If the Soliton is unable to resolve the grievance informally, he/she should raise the matter, by writing to the 
People Manag er 
Then,  
A meeting will be arranged to discuss the matter with the Soliton who raised  the grievance. Wherever 
possible, the meeting will be scheduled to take place within five working days.  
Then,  
The Soliton will receive a letter/ e mail confirming the outcome of the grievance meeting, normally within 
seven working days of the meeting.  
Then,  
If the individual remains dissatisfied with the outcome of the grievance process, he/she can write to the MD 
who will review  the case.  
 The timelines above are intended to be used as a guideline and followed in most cases. But there may be 
times where key participants in the proce ss are not available, for example, due to holiday or where the 
matter is especially complex and requires detailed investigation. In such circumstances Solitons will be told 
the date by which he / she can expect a response and every effort will be made to c omplete the process as 
quickly as possible.

Confidentiality    
Solitons are free to discuss all aspects of their concerns without fear of getting judged or the information 
getting improperly disclosed. A high level of confidentiality will be always maintained covering all kinds of 
information that got exchanged in the process.   
 Each grievance may be different, raising different issues and problems. Hence they will be handled, in 
accordance with the  individual circumstances.   
Anonymity    
To address a grievance, it may be necessary to disclose the identity of the Soliton to the respondent to 
ensure adherence to the principles of fairness and natural justice. As part of the initial assessment, the 
People manager will discuss requests for an onymity and explore whether they are feasible.   
Protection    
Solitons can be rest assured that raising any kind of grievance will not adversely affect them. All grievances 
will be handled with all possible care, sensitivity and discretion while protecting the sensibilities of the 
affected Soliton.

Guidelines of Fast Track Promotion   
The Fast Track Promotion policy aims to foster an environment that allows for a faster growth 
path within Soliton.  Through these promotions high potential, meritorious Solitons who have 
shown outstanding performance consistently, can take up next level roles and responsibilities.  
All confirmed Solitons with a minimum tenure of 1 year in Soliton are eligible to apply or to get 
nominated for the Fast Track Promotion. Solitons who are under a  performance improvement 
plan  are excluded from this program.  
• Acceptable criteria for nomination are:   
 High performance level in [ two] recent review cycles, with a rating of ES or above  
 Experience in the function and/or role  
 Skillsets that match the minimum requirements of the new role  
 Personal motivation and willingness to accept a change in role and responsibilities

• Nomination process  
 Self-nomination  – Solitons who meet the above -mentioned criteria for the 
nomination can send the self -nomination when they feel that they are ready to 
take up the next level role/responsibility.  
 Manager nomination  – Managers can send the nomination for team members who 
have shown outstanding performance consistently and have begun taking up 
additional responsibilities, beyond their current scope of work.   
In addition to the acceptable criteria, some guidelin es are given in the next section.  This is 
additional input for managers as they evaluate the readiness of the person to take up the new 
role.  
The nomination must be downloaded, filled in and mailed to anu.antony@solitontech.com   
Fast Track Promotion allows for Solitons to move to roles that are one level above their current 
role. In a particular month if a Soliton is due for promotion, he/she can send the self -nomination 
for the role/level which is one level above the role/level to which promotion is due.  
The above points are applicable for Manager nominations as well.

• Knowing when to nominate a person for Fast Track Promotion   
Guideline for Managers   
 Excels well beyond expectations  
 Goes above and beyond the job description  
 Shows a great deal of commitment to their work  
 Willingly takes on new responsibilities without  being asked  
 Finds ways to get results by adapting and innovating  
 Demonstrates mastery in their current job function/role  
 Requires little to no close supervision  
 Shows ownership for the success of the Project/Team  
 •  Applicable roles   
Solitons can apply for Fast Track Promotion to the following roles of all tracks   
 Senior Engineer / Executive  
 Lead   
 Senior Lead  
 Project Manager / Manager

• Selection process  
The selection process will comprise of assessment  of perfo rmance and initiatives taken in 
the current role, demonstration  of leadership skills, evidence  of potential/ability to take 
up the roles and responsibilities of the new role.   
In addition, an interview may be held with the nominee before the final decisio n.  
• Timeline for Nomination  
There is no timeline for sending the nomination. Solitons can self -nominate and managers 
can nominate anytime throughout the year.

Guidelines/Etiquette for the Virtual Connects  
As the home and workplace are merged into one during the ‘work from home’ set -up, the boundaries 
between our personal and professional lives have also started to blur. During an online meeting, multiple 
awkward situations are bound to occur.  
With an increase in remote work, we are being introduced to new ways of working, and there are a lot of 
things we are yet to learn. Guides to remote work can help us with this, but it begins with connecting with 
the teammates in the right way. To ensure that your presence and appearance on screen remains 
consistent throughout the meetings, here are some guidelines.  
• Inform participants and seek their consent before scheduling a video call.  
• Send the intimation well in advance and take consensus for meetings that happen outside of work 
hours.  
• Do not insist that female colleagues enable the vide o during the calls; offer the option to attend 
calls in “audio -only” mode.   
• Have your settings on mute & no video while joining the video call. Background noise and 
movement can be a distraction and interrupt a meeting’s flow.  
• Be mindful of your clothing and the background.

Guidelines/Etiquette for the Virtual Connects  
• Always choose a place with a simple solid color background such as a wall and not with a place 
that displays many things behind you. Anyone listening to you should not be distracted with what 
is in the backg round. They should be able to focus on your face and what you are saying.  
• Ensure you are on time for the meeting.  
• Always start the meeting by introducing each other and the meeting agenda as concisely as 
possible so everyone can have a context.  
• Have res pectful and professional conversations.  
• Restrict the conversation on official communication channels to work related topics.  
• Meetings require everyone to be focused and alert. Everyone’s time should be utilized .  
• Facilitate the meeting so every attendee is able to provide their best suggestions, ideas, and 
opinions and participate fully in the discussion.   
• Make sure to not indulge in other unrelated tasks during the meeting.   
• Do not interrupt anyone as they are speaking. There is usually some lag during  online meetings 
and the response usually reaches a bit later, so allow for a couple of seconds, before you say 
something.

Guidelines/Etiquette for the Virtual Connects  
• Make it a habit to wrap up a meeting on time.  If a topic requires more time, seek consensus and 
schedule a follow -up meeting.  
• Make  a note of key decisions and action points with owners and timelines in a shared document 
that is viewable by all during the meeting, and is available for reference after the meeting is 
wrapped up.  Online meetings have become a daily part of our professio nal life. By following the Etiquette for the Virtual 
Connects , we can easily stay more productive and engaged during meetings.

Guiding principles on “work -life balance”   
1. Family and health first, work next  
a. We should never feel like we have to put Soliton’s interest above our family’s interest 
or our physical or mental wellbeing. Soliton can ensure that commitments to customers 
are met without asking you to sacrifice your health or what is important to your f amily. 
When it comes to making a choice between your family / health and a business need, 
the choice is clear and stated clearly as our Principle #1.  
b. It goes without saying that we will be professional and give as much advance intimation 
as possible if we are not going to be able to meet a commitment so that our colleagues 
can step in and help address any gap, and the customer can prepare accordingly if  
necessary.

2. We choose how much we want to work  
a. None of us should feel compelled to take on more work than we want to. 45 hours of 
work per week is the expectation. We are free to do more if we chose to, but if we are 
getting more work than we are comfo rtable handling, we should talk to our lead/manager 
to have this addressed.  
b. We are empowered to choose the work timings that works best for us. We understand 
that our performance will be evaluated based on our overall contribution and results, 
and not on the hours we spend on work.  
c. We should feel free to leave the office / step away from work at any time to take care of 
our personal work and catch up on the work commitments later. The primary expectation 
is that we are dependable, and we meet the commitme nts that we make to customers or 
to our colleagues. And when we are not able to meet a commitment for any reason, we 
intimate and get permission ahead of time.  
d. Even if senior members or others in the team are spending long hours in the office, there 
is no  expectation to extend our working hours to match them. As mentioned above, this 
is our choice. But if the team is going through a rough patch that demands more time, 
there is an expectation that we will be a good team player and step up to help the team 
through this phase, provided we are able to (there may be important family commitments 
that may not give us the flexibility and in that case, family takes precedence).

3. We don’t have to say “yes” to every request, we are encouraged to arrive at winwin 
agreements through pleasant negotiation  
a. When a customer (or a colleague) asks for something that is going to inconvenience us, 
we should explore alternatives that will stil l serve the purpose, rather than feel like we 
have to say yes right away. For example, suggest a different meeting time that will work 
for both sides, explain why the timeline suggested by the customer to finish something 
is not sufficient and ask for time  to come with back with our estimate after an analysis, 
etc.  
b. Most customers (and all colleagues) will be willing to listen and accommodate unless 
they have some hard compulsion.  
4. We are encouraged to take steps to have more focused shorter work times  
a. We are encouraged to inculcate disciplined work habits that will restrict the working 
hours to confined high productivity periods, and release time to take care of health 
(exercise), family time, and time with friends. For example, no distraction hours.  
b. This may not look to be important at the start of our careers when we do not have other 
commitments, but after marriage and children, this will be essential. And it is never too 
early to start exercising and reading.

Leave Policy   
The Leave Policy is a set of guidelines for availing leave by Solitons based in India.   
Eligibility    
This Policy is applicable to all full -time (permanent role) Solitons, based in offices in India.

Overview of Leave types  
Leave Type   
No. of days    
Key Points  
Privilege Leave  20 per year*  Credited @20 days per year  
Carry forward of max 30 days  
Encashable at the time of retirement/separation  
Sick Leave  12 per year*  Credited at the beginning of the year  
No carry forward or accumulation No 
encashment  
Maternity Leave  26 weeks  For upto 2 live births during a women Solitons’ 
tenure in Soliton  
Paternity Leave  15 days  15 working days per childbirth  
Can be taken anytime during the first 6 months 
of the birth of the newborn  
National/Festival/Holidays  10 per year  To be declared by the Company every year  
Leave without Pay  1 year  1 year of every completed 2 years’ tenure in  
Soliton  
Compensatory Off  NA  1 working day for every weekly off day/  
National/Festival holiday worked on  
(*January – December | Calendar year)

1. Privilege Leave (PL)    
a) Solitons are entitled to PL of 20 working days in a calendar year. Leaves are credited at the 
beginning of every calendar year after the completion of 1 year.   
b) For new joiners, PL credit will be prorated to the number of days remaining in the year, based on 
their date of joining. Any fraction will be rounded off to half -a-day.   
c) Intervening weekly offs and National/ Festival holidays will not be included in calculating the number 
of days of PL availed.   
d) However, if a Soliton is on leave without pay, holid ays or weekly off days before or after such leave 
will be treated as Loss of Pay days.   
e) PL should be availed preferably with prior approval of the authorized Project Manager/ Leader   
f) Un-availed PLs, if any, up to a maximum of 30 days can be carried forwa rd to the next calendar 
year. Any accrued PLs, in excess of 30 days, will get lapsed at the end of the calendar year.   
g) Accrued PLs, if any, up to a maximum of 30 days can be encashed at the time of retirement/ 
separation from the company.   
h) Leave encashment is calculated based on the last drawn Base salary using the formula (Monthly 
Gross Salary * Number of leave being encashed) / 26. The Monthly Gross Salary comprises the  
following components - Basic, Dearness Allowance and Basket of Allowan ces. The number 26 is 
the number of working days in a month, assumed as standard for all months in a year, for the 
purpose of computation of Leave Encashment.   
i) Leave encashment will be processed along with full and final settlement. Such payments shall be 
governed by the Income Tax Act and applicable tax liability should be borne by the Soliton being 
relieved.

2. Sick Leave (SL)    
a) Solitons are entitled to 12 days of Sick Leave in a calendar year, credited at the beginning of 
each year.   
b) This lea ve can be availed on medical grounds only.   
c) For new joiners, SL credit will be prorated to the number of days remaining in the year, based 
on their date of joining. Any fraction will be rounded off to half -a-day.    
d) SL can neither be carried forward to th e next calendar year, nor encashed at the time of 
retirement/ separation. The balance SL will lapse at the end of the calendar year.

3. Maternity Leave (ML)    
a) Expecting women Solitons, who have put in a minimum of 80 days of service, in the past 12  
months, in the organization, are entitled to 26 calendar weeks of paid maternity leave, for up to 
two live births during the woman Soliton’s service with the company.   
b) The twenty -six (26) calendar weeks are inclusive of National/ Festival holidays.   
c) During the loss of pay period/Maternity break, any types of leave will not be granted.  
d) ML can be availed starting 8 weeks before expected date of delivery.   
e) Post return to work from ML, the new mother can avail flexible working hours for 3 months at 
full pay, provided she is able to meet the requirement of 45 hours of work, per week, for every 
week in a given month.   
f) ML cannot be accumulated or availed in ins talments and is not encashable under any 
circumstance.   
g) 12 weeks’ paid maternity leave is applicable for the third or later child, as per the prevailing 
Maternity Act (2016).   
h) In case of adoption, if the age of the child is less than 6 months, the adopti ng mother is entitled 
to 12 weeks’ paid maternity leave. Commissioning mothers are also eligible for 12 weeks’ paid 
maternity leave.   
i) In case of miscarriage, a woman Soliton shall, on production of proof as may be prescribed by 
a medical practitioner (For m-B), be entitled to leave with pay, for a period of 6 weeks 
immediately following the day of the miscarriage. The requirement of proof and completion of 
Form -B is a mandatory requirement as per the Indian Government’s Maternity Act. ML will not 
be applica ble in this case.   
j) The woman Soliton, who avails ML, undertakes to not take up alternate employment and/ or 
engage in any work elsewhere, with or without pay, during the period she is on ML.

4. Paternity Leave (PTL)  
a) Solitons are entitled to PTL of 15 working days per childbirth. Leaves are credited at the 
beginning of every calendar year after the completion of 1 year.   
b) For new joiners, PTL credit will be credited upon confirmation.   
c) PTL is not encashable.

5. Na tional/ Festival Holidays    
a) The company shall announce a maximum of 10 National/ Festival holidays in a year based on 
the mandatory holidays prescribed by the Central/ State government and other social/ religious 
considerations.   
b) List of National/ Festival Holidays will be published in December every year, for the upcoming 
calendar year.

6. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
a) Solitons, based on their superior work performance, at the discretion of the Manager and/ or 
Sr. Leadership , can avail LwoP for up to 1 year, for personal reasons of an exigent and 
demanding nature.   
b) To avail of this leave benefit, a Soliton should have been in continuous service with the 
Company for a minimum of 2 years.   
c) The leave benefit would be calculate d as 1 year of LwoP for every completed 2 years’ tenure 
in Soliton. ‘Completed tenure’ refers to working full time in any of the Soliton offices or at client 
site.   
d) LwoP could be availed for personal reasons like extended leave for childcare, over and abo ve 
the benefits under ML Policy, emergency situations in the family or travel with spouse to onsite 
locations (spouse could be working with other companies), or higher education, or any other 
unplanned and emergency personal situation. Specific approval ne eds to be taken from The 
People Team and Delivery Head for availing this benefit.   
e) New role for Solitons returning to work post completion of LwoP, will be determined based on 
available, and relevant, openings at that point in time.

6. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
f) Increment and Promot ion: In case a salary review or a promotion exercise is conducted during 
the period of absence of the Soliton, the individual would not be eligible for either an increment 
or a promotion in that particular cycle.   
g) Provident Fund: The Company’s contributio n towards the Employees Provident Fund, for 
eligible Solitons, would cease for this period. As the PF contribution is calculated on Basic 
salary, it will not be paid for the duration when there is no salary payout for the individual.   
h) Gratuity: The durati on of LwoP would be considered for the payment of Gratuity, in line with the 
conditions for the same, as laid down by the Payment of Gratuity Act. Since such leave is 
considered as period of “continuous service”, as per the Act, Gratuity will accrue for th e whole 
period.   
i) PL eligibility: The period in which the Soliton avails this benefit would not be considered as 
continuous service to the Company for the purpose of privilege leave entitlement, i.e. PL will 
not be credited for the period the Soliton is on  LwoP.   
j) Insurance: For the period of LwoP, the Soliton would continue to be covered under the 
Company’s Insurance Policy.

6. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
k) LwoP includes weekends and any declared National/ Festival holidays.   
l) LwoP cannot be accumulated or carried forward, under any cir cumstance.

7. Compensatory Off (Comp off)    
a) If a Soliton is required to work, on an important work assignment on a declared holiday/ weekly -
off day, s/he would be eligible to apply for Comp off on any other working day.   
b) Prior approval is required from the Project Manager/ Lead to work on National holidays/ 
declared holidays/ weekly off days.    
c) Comp off can be granted only if a Soliton has at tended work in person, either in office or at 
onsite. It is also  extended to Solitons, who have worked from home, on the given day with prior 
intimation.   
d) The credited Comp off has to be availed within a period of 90 days from the date he/she worked.   
e) Comp offs, when not availed within the stipulated time period, will get lapsed. It cannot be 
carried forward or accumulated under any circumstance.

8. Privilege Leave for Probationers    
During the probation period, a maximum of 2 days of Privilege Leave may be availed during the 
first 3 months and another 4 days of Privilege Leave during the remaining period of 3 months.

9. Leave for Solitons on part/ flexi -time work arrangements:    
Solitons on part/flexi -time work arrangements are entitled to National/ Festival Holidays, as 
declared by the company every year. The standard Leave Policy is applicable on a pro -rata basis 
to Solitons who avail of the part -time wo rking mode on a fixed proportion basis. Those on hourly 
pay will not have any paid leave eligibility.

10. Leave for Solitons based in work locations outside India:    
Solitons based in work locations outside India would be governed by the applicable l aws and 
required legal compliance in the each host country.

Leave/ Paid Time Off Policy - Soliton Technologies, Inc  
The Leave Policy is a set of guidelines for Solitons who are working with Soliton Technologies, 
Inc (US Solitons).

Overview of Leave types:  
Leave Type   
No. of days    
Key Points  
Paid Time Off (PTO)  20 per year*  Credited @20 days per year   
Carry forward of max 5 days   
Encashable at the time of retirement/separation  
Maternity Leave  30 days  Applicable for women Solitons; 30 days for each 
live birth  
Paternity Leave  7 days  7 working days per childbirth  
Can be taken anytime during the first 6 months 
of the birth of the newborn  
Leave on Compensation (LoC)  NA  Can be availed for working on any 
Saturday/Sunday/declared holiday  
(*January – December | Calendar year)

1. Paid Time Off (PTO)  
a) Solitons are entitled to PTO of 20 working days in a calendar year. Leaves are credited at the 
beginning of every calendar year after the completion of 1 year.   
b) For new joiners, PL credit will be prorated to the number of days remaining in the year, based  on 
their date of joining. Any fraction will be rounded off to half -a-day. Similarly for resignees, PTO 
eligibility will be pro -rated based on the no,of days worked in the year.  
c) Intervening weekly offs and National/ Festival holidays will not be included in calculating the 
number of days of PTO availed.   
d) However, if a Soliton is on leave without pay, holidays or weekly off days before or after such 
leave will be treated as Loss of Pay days.   
e) Un-availed PLs, if any, up to a maximum of 5 days can be carrie d forward to the next calendar 
year. Any accrued PLs, in excess of 5 days, will get lapsed at the end of the calendar year.   
f) Accrued PLs, if any, can be encashed at the time of retirement/ separation from the company.   
g) Leave encashment is calculated base d on the last drawn salary using the formula (Annual 
salary/2000*no. of PTO hours.   
h) Leave encashment will be processed along with full and final settlement.

2. Maternity Leave (ML)   
a) Expecting women Solitons with atleast 1 year of experience, are entitled to 1 month of paid 
maternity leave for each liv e birth.   
b) A further unpaid maternity leave can be taken upto 12 weeks by all women Solitons 
irrespective of the years of experience.   
c) ML cannot be accumulated or availed in instalments and is not encashable under any 
circumstance.

3. Paternity Leave (PTL)  
  a) Solitons with atleast 1 year of experience are entitled to PTL of 7 working days per childbirth. 
Leaves are credited at the beginning of every calendar year.   
b) A further unpaid Paternity leave can be taken upto 12 weeks by Solitons  irrespective of the 
years of experience.  
c) PTL is not encashable.

4. Leave on Compensation (LoC)  
  Solitons can avail the leave of compensation only for the days already worked, with prior approval  
 from their respective managers.  
a) LoC can be availed f or working on any Saturday/Sunday/declared holiday.  
b) LoC duly approved by the manager / Equivalent Authority should be submitted along with the 
leave application.

5. Medical leave  
Solitons with atleast 1 year of experience are entitled to unpaid Medical leave each year for  
 any of the following reasons. The duration of the unpaid leave will need to be discussed with 
and   approved by the reporting manager,   
a) To care for an immediat e family member (i.e., spouse, child, or parent) with a serious health 
condition;   
b) To take medical leave when Soliton is unable to work because of a serious health condition.

Procedure for availing Leave  
a) Solitons have to apply for leaves (PTO / ML / P TL / LoC) through the HRMS system 
(GreytHR) well in advance.   
b) In case of emergencies, the leave details can be updated in the system upon returning to 
duty. This has to be done on the day of returning.  
c) The notice period recommended for planned leave is t wo weeks in advance. In general, 
please provide as much advance notice as possible.

Making the Soliton Handbook an Open Source  
Guidelines  
The Soliton handbook is a consolidated document that provides guidance and information 
related to the organization’s policies, procedures and benefits and helps to establish Soliton’s 
culture and expectations.   
While framing a policy, it is important to take into consideration that it acts as a guide for every 
Soliton. The policy can be edited by any Soliton with comments that include their perspective, 
questions or concerns. While making edits, the individual’s rationale for such a change has to be 
menti oned.  
New policy Edits can be classified as  
1. Simple Edits – Which will be review ed by HR and added back to the policy immediately  
2. Complex Edits – The deci sion to make such cha nges will be through a voting process  
 The team will review the comments once in 2 weeks and include the changes in the policy.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harassment at Workplace (POSH)   
Soliton Technologies (hereinafter “the Company”) is committed to creating and maintaining a secure work 
environment where all Solitons, vendors and partners can work and pursue business together in an 
atmosphere free of exploitation and intimidation caused  by acts of sexual harassment, within but not limited 
to, the office premises and other locations directly related to the company’s business. Soliton firmly believes 
that all Solitons should be treated with dignity and respect and expects everyone to promo te a sense of 
personal responsibility.   
 This Policy has been framed in accordance with the provisions of “The Sexual Harassment of Women at 
Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013” and rules framed thereunder (hereinafter 
“the Act”). Accordingly, while the Policy covers all t he key aspects of the Act, for any further clarification 
reference shall always be made to the Act and the provisions of the Act shall prevail.  
The objective of this Policy is to provide protection against sexual harassment at the workplace and the 
preven tion and redressal of complaints of sexual harassment and matters related to it.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Scope   
This policy applies to all Solitons (full -time, part -time, interns, trainees, and those on contractual 
assignments) of the Company including all subsidiaries and aff iliated companies, at their workplace or at 
client sites. The company will not tolerate sexual harassment, if engaged in by clients, suppliers, or any 
other business associates.  
Definitions

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
1. What is Sexual Harassment?   
Sexual harassment includes an y one or more of the following unwelcome acts or behavior (whether directly 
or by implication):  
a) Any unwelcome sexually determined behavior, or pattern of conduct, that would cause discomfort 
and/ or humiliate a person at whom the behavior or conduct was directed namely:   
i. Physical contact and advances.   
ii. Demand or request for sexual favors.  iii.  Sexually colored remarks or remarks of a sexual 
nature about a person's clothing or body.   
iv. Showing pornography, making or posting sexual pranks, sexual teasing, sexual jokes, 
sexually demeaning or offensive pictur es, cartoons or other materials through email, SMS, 
MMS, Whatsapp, social media, etc.   
v. Repeatedly asking to socialize during off -duty hours or continued expressions of sexual 
interest against a person’s wishes. Giving gifts or leaving objects that are sexu ally 
suggestive.   
vi. Eve teasing, innuendos and taunts, physical confinement against one’s will or any such 
act likely to intrude upon one’s privacy. Persistent watching, following, contacting of a

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
1. What is Sexual Harassment?   
person.   
vii. Any other unwelcome physical, verbal, or non -verbal conduct of sexual nature.   
b) The following circumstances if it occurs, or is present, in relation to any sexually determined act or 
behavior amount to sexual harassment:   
 i. Implied or explicit promise of preferential treatment in employment  ii. I mplied or explicit threat of 
detrimental treatment in employment iii. Implied or explicit threat about the present or future 
employment status iv. Interference with the person’s work or creating an intimidating or offensive or 
hostile work environment  
v. Humiliating treatment likely to affect health or safety  
It is important to note that whether harassment has occurred or not does not depend on the intention of 
people but on the experience of the aggrieved woman.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
2. Aggrieved woman   
In relation to  a workplace, a woman, of any age, whether employed or not, who alleges to have been 
subjected to any act of sexual harassment and includes people on contract and temporary visitors.  
3. Respondent   
A person against whom a complaint of sexual harassment has been made by an aggrieved Woman. In the 
event that the respondent is not a Soliton of the Company, the POSH Committee shall, as and when the 
need arises, device the process to conduct enquiries and to assist the complainant to file the complaint 
before  the right redressal forum.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
4. Complainant   
A complaint may be filed on behalf of the aggrieved woman if the woman is incapacitated. Such complaint 
maybe filed by a relative, friend, colleague, or any person with the knowledge of the incident, provided such 
person has knowledge of the incident.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
5. Workplace   
All offices or other premises where the Company’s business is conducted  
All company -related activities performed at any other site away from the Company’s premises.  
Any social, business, or othe r functions where the conduct or comments may have an adverse impact on 
the workplace or workplace relations.  
Any place where the aggrieved woman or the respondent visits in connection with his/ her work, during 
the course of and/ or arising out of employ ment/ contract/ engagement with the Company, including 
transportation provided for undertaking such a journey.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
6. Employer   
A person responsible for management, supervision, and control of the workplace at the Company.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Roles and Responsibilities   
a) Responsibilities of individuals: It is the responsibility of all Solitons to respect the rights of others and to 
never encourage harassment. It can be done by:    
i. Refusing to participate in any activity which constitutes harassment   
ii. Supporting the person to reject unwelcome behavior   
iii. Acting as a witness, if the person being harassed decides to lodge a complaint   
All Solitons are encouraged to advise one another of behavior that is unwelcome. Often, some 
behaviors are not intentional; while this does not make it acceptable, it does give the person 
behaving inappropriately, the opportunity to modify or stop their of fensive behavior.  
b) Responsibilities of Supervisors: All Solitons in supervisory roles (SPEs, PLs, PMs, Team Managers, BU 
Managers, etc.) must ensure that all Solitons in their teams understand that harassment will not be 
tolerated and that complaints wil l be taken seriously.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Complaints Redressal Mechanism   
In compliance with the Act, for the complaint to warrant formal intervention, the complainant needs to lodge 
a written complaint, which shall be followed by a formal redressal mechanism as described in this Policy. 
In case of a verbal complaint, the complaint will be recorded in writing by the receiver of the complaint and 
signatures of the complainant will be obtained.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
a. Internal Complaints Committee (hereinafter “ICC”)   
The responsibility for admi nistering this Policy rests with the Internal Complaints Committee (hereinafter 
“ICC”) as required under the Act. ICC is constituted in order to prevent instances of sexual harassment and 
to receive and effectively deal with complaints pertaining to the sa me.  
The ICC comprises:  
i. Presiding Officer: A Senior woman Soliton of the company ii. Two 
members from Human Resources/ People Operations department  iii. 
One external member from an NGO or an advocate.  
iii. Employer: A person responsible for managemen t, supervision, and control of the workplace at the 
Company.  
The ICC is responsible for:  
a) Investigating every formal written complaint of sexual harassment   
b) Taking appropriate remedial measures to respond to any substantiated allegations of sexual 
harassment   
c) Submitting findings and recommendations of inquiries to designated authorities   
d) Coordinating with the employer in implementing appropriate action   
e) Mainta ining strict confidentiality throughout the process as per established guidelines   
f) Submitting annual reports in the prescribed format to designated authorities   
g) Discouraging and preventing employment -related sexual harassment

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
b. Lodging a complaint   
A complainant/ aggrieved woman can file a complaint with the ICC within a period a 3 months from the date 
of the incident and in case of a series of incidents within 3 months from the date of last incident. The ICC 
may extend the time limit of 3 months if it is satisfied with the reasons of the delay in filing the complaint; 
the reasons for delay needs to be submitted in writing to the ICC.  
A written complaint providing the name, department and details of the incident may be sent via email to 
POSH@solitonte ch.com . The recipient of this email would be the presiding officer of ICC and all emails 
sent to this ID will be treated with utmost confidentiality.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
c. Conducting the inquiry   
The ICC may, before initiating an inquiry and at the request of the aggrieved woman, take steps to settle 
the matter between her and the respondent through conciliation as stated under Section 10 of the Act. 
However, no monetary settlement shall be made as  a basis of such conciliation. It is also made clear to all 
parties that conciliation in itself doesn’t necessarily mean acceptance of complaint by the respondent. It is 
a practical mechanism through which issues are resolved or misunderstandings cleared.  
In case a settlement is arrived at, the ICC records & reports the same to the employer for taking appropriate 
action. Resolution through conciliation happens within 2 weeks of receipt of complaint. The ICC provides 
copies of the settlement to complainant &  respondent. Once the action is implemented, no further inquiry 
is conducted.  
The ICC initiates inquiry in the following cases:  
a) No conciliation is requested by aggrieved woman   
b) Conciliation has not resulted in any settlement   
c) Complainant informs the ICC that any terms or conditions of the settlement arrived through 
conciliation, has not been complied with, by the respondent(s)   
The ICC proceeds to make an inquiry into the complaint within a period of 1 week of its receipt of the original 
complaint/ closure of conciliation/ repeat complaint.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Manner of inquiry into complaint   
a) Complainant should submit the complaint along with supporting documents and the names of the 
witnesses   
b) Upon receipt of the complaint, the ICC sends 1 copy of the complaint to respondent within 7 working 
days   
c) Respondent replies with all supporting documents within 10 working days of receiving the copy of 
the complaint   
d) No legal practitioner can represent an y party at any stage of the inquiry procedure   
e) The ICC makes inquiry into the complaint in accordance with the principles of natural justice   
f) In conducting the inquiry, a minimum of three ICC members including the Presiding Officer is 
present    
During pen dency of the inquiry, on a written request made by the complainant, the ICC may recommend to 
the employer to -  
a) Transfer the complainant or the respondent to any other workplace   
b) Grant leave to the aggrieved woman of maximum 3 months, in addition to the le ave she would 
otherwise be entitled   
c) Prevent the respondent from assessing complainant’s work performance   
d) Grant such other relief as may be appropriate

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Termination of Inquiry   
ICC may terminate the inquiry or give ex -parte decision, if complainant or respondent respectively is absent 
for 3 consecutive hearings, without reason. 15 day written notice to be given to the party, before termination 
or ex -parte order.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Inquiry proced ure  
All proceedings of the inquiry is documented. ICC interviews the respondent separately and impartially.  
a) ICC states exactly what the allegation is and who has made the allegation. The respondent is given 
full opportunity to respond and provide any e vidence etc.   
b) Detailed notes of the meetings are prepared which may be shared with the respondent and 
complainant upon request.   
c) Any witnesses produced by the respondent are also interviewed & statements are taken.   
d) In case complainant or respondent seeks to ask questions to the other party, they may give them 
to ICC, which asks them and records the statement of the other party.   
e) Any such inquiry is completed, including the submission of the inquiry report, within 90 days from 
the date on which the inquiry is commenced.   
f) The inquiry procedure ensures absolute fairness to all parties.   
g) A copy of the proceedings were made available to both parties enabling them to make 
representation against the findings.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Complaint un substantiated   
Where ICC arrives at the conclusion that the allegation against the respondent has not been proven, it 
recommends to the employer that no action is required to be taken in this matter.  
Further, ICC ensures that both parties understand that the matter has been fully investigated, that the matter 
is now concluded, and neither will be disadvantaged within the company.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Complaint substantiated   
Where ICC arrives at the conclusion that the allegation against the respondent has been proven, it 
recommends to the employer, to take necessary action, in accordance with the applicable service rules and 
policies, and this may include:  
 a) Counseling   
b) Cens ure or reprimand   
c) Apology to be tendered by respondent   
d) Written warning   
e) Withholding promotion and/ or increments   
f) Suspension   
g) Termination   
h) Or any other action that the employer and the Company management may deem fit  The 
employer acts upon the recommendat ions within 60 days and confirms to the ICC.  
Post implementation of the actions follow up with the aggrieved woman/ complainant occurs to ascertain 
whether the behavior has in fact stopped, the solution is working satisfactorily, and that no victimization  of 
either party has occurred. This follow up is undertaken by the complainant/ aggrieved woman’s supervisor, 
supported by People Manger..

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Malicious Allegations   
Where ICC arrives at the conclusion that the allegation against the respondent is malicious  or the aggrieved 
woman or the complainant has made the complaint knowing it to be false or has forged or produced 
misleading document, it may recommend to the employer to take action against the aggrieved woman or 
the complainant.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Appeal   
Any party not satisfied or further aggrieved by the implementation or non -implementation of 
recommendations made, may appeal to the appellate authority in accordance with the Act and rules, 
within 90 days of the recommendations being communicated.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Guidelines for members of the Internal Complaints Committee   
a) Believe in the reality of the complaint lodged.   
b) Empathize with the complainant. Do not function like a criminal court.   
c) Remember that it may be difficult for an Soliton to talk about anything ‘sexual’. Hence there can be 
a long time interval between the harassment and the actual complaint.   
d) Handle complaints in a confidential manner and within the stipulated time period.   
e) Submit annual report on sexual harassment cases, if any, and actions taken to address the same, 
to the CEO, Head of Human Resources and/ or designated authority.   
f) Maintain all the data related to sexual harassment cases in the company. Document results of a ny 
sexual harassment complaint or investigation. Not only the results, but also document any 
corrective action that the Soliton or supervisor was asked to take.   
g) Provide safety for the complainant and his / her supporters, if such a need be felt and that t he ICC 
can recommend action against persons indulging in intimidation of the complainant or witness to a 
complaint.   
h) Discard predetermined notions of how an accused should look or behave or dress. Be aware of 
stereotypes.

metadata.file_name: Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf
Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harrassment at Workplace.pdf

__data__.text:
Guidelines for members of the Internal Complaints Committee   
i) Do not insist on detailed description of harassment. This could increase the aggrieved woman/ 
complainant’s trauma.   
j) Most sexual crimes are committed in private; hence there may not be any eyewitnesses. Since this 
is a human rights issue, balance of probabilities is a sufficient measure of proof.    
 k) Help the complainant regain his / her self -respect.     
l) Make ‘discreet’ enquiries as to whether other Solito ns have experienced similar problems.   
m) Inform all Solitons that it is their obligation to report sexual harassment that they either experience 
or witness.   
n) The inability to substantiate a complaint or provide adequate proof need not attract action against 
the aggrieved woman/ complainant.

1. General Policies and Procedures  
A. Guiding Principles on “Work -life Balance”  
1. Family and health first, work next   
a. We should never feel like we have to  put Soliton’s interest above our family’s interest or our physical 
or mental wellbeing. Soliton can ensure that commitments to customers are met without asking us 
to sacrifice our health or what is important to our family. When it comes to making a choice  between 
family / health and a business need, the choice is clear and stated clearly as our Principle #1.  
b. It goes without saying that we will be professional and give as much advance intimation as possible 
if we are not going to be able to meet a commit ment so that our colleagues can step in and help 
bridge the gap, if necessary, and the customer can prepare accordingly.

We choose how much we want to work   
a. None of us should feel compelled to take on more work than we want to. 45 hours of work per week 
is the expectation. We are free to do more if we chose to, but if we are getting more work than we 
are comfortable handling, we should talk to our lead/manager  to have this addressed.  
b. We are empowered to choose the work timings that work best for us. We understand that our 
performance will be evaluated based on our overall contribution and results, and not on the hours 
we spend on work.  
c. We should feel free  to leave the office / step away from work at any time to take care of our personal 
work and catch up on the work commitments later. The primary expectation is that we are 
dependable, and we meet the commitments that we make to customers or to our colleagu es. And 
when we are not able to meet a commitment for any reason, we intimate and get permission ahead 
of time.  
d. Even if senior members or others in the team are spending long hours in the office, there is no 
expectation to extend our working hours to ma tch them. As mentioned above, this is our choice. 
But if the team is going through a rough patch that demands more time, there is an expectation that 
we will be a good team player and step up to help the team through this phase, provided we are 
able to (th ere may be important family commitments that may not give us the flexibility and, in that 
case, family takes precedence).

We do not have to say “yes” to every request, we are encouraged to arrive at win -win 
agreements through pleasant negotiation.  
a. When a customer (or a colleague) asks for something that is going to inconvenience us, we should 
explore alternatives that will still serve the purpose, rather than feel like we have to say yes right 
away. For example, suggest a different meeting time that  will work for both sides, explain why the 
timeline suggested by the customer to finish something is not sufficient and ask for time to come 
with back with our estimate after an analysis, etc.  
b. Most customers (and all colleagues) will be willing to liste n and accommodate unless they have 
some urgent compulsion.

We are encouraged to take steps to have more focused shorter work times  
a. We are encouraged to inculcate disciplined work habits that will restrict the working hours with  
planned high produc tivity periods, and release time to take care of health (exercise), family, and 
social time with friends. For example, we can schedule no distraction hours.  
b. This may not seem to be important at the start of our careers when we do not have other 
commitme nts, but after marriage and children, this will be essential. And it is never too early to start 
exercising and reading.

B. Dress Code  
We do not have any dress code. Dress appropriately.

C. Etiquette for the Virtual Connects  
As the home and workplace are merged into one during the ‘work from home’ set -up, the boundaries 
between our personal and professional lives have also started to blur. During an online meeting, multiple 
awkward situation s are bound to occur.  
With an increase in remote work, we are being introduced to new ways of working, and there are a lot of 
things we are yet to learn. Guides to remote work can help us with this, but it begins with connecting with 
the teammates in the right way. To ensure that our presence and appearance on screen remains consistent 
throughout the meetings, here are some guidelines.  
a) Let’s ensure to inform participants and seek their consent before scheduling a video call.  
b) Send the intimation well in a dvance and take consensus for meetings that happen outside of work 
hours.  
c) Let’s not insist our colleagues to enable the video during the calls; offer the option to attend calls in 
“audio -only” mode.  
d) Have the settings on mute & disable video [if not neces sary] while joining the call. Background 
noise and movement can be a distraction and interrupt a meeting’s flow.  
e) Let’s be mindful of our clothing and the background.

C. Etiquette for the Virtual Connects  
f) We are encouraged to choose a place with a simple solid color background such as a wall and not 
with a place that displays many things behind us. Anyone listening to us should not be distracted 
with what is in the background. They should be able to focus on our face and what we are saying. 
g) Let’s ensure to be on time for the meeting.  
h) Let’s  not indulge in other unrelated tasks during the meeting.  
i) Let’s not interrupt anyone as they are speaking. There is usually some lag during online meetings 
and the response usually reaches a bit later, so allow for a couple of seconds before we say 
someth ing.  
j) Let’s make it a habit to wrap up a meeting on time. If a topic requires more time, seek consensus 
and schedule a follow -up meeting.  
Online meetings have become a daily part of our professional life. By following the Etiquette for the Virtual 
Connect s, we can easily stay more productive and engaged during meetings.

D. Workplace Communication  
All Solitons are expected to communicate work related matters in English within the office and on all official 
engagements.

E. Ethics  
At Soliton, we are committed to ensuring Integrity and Excellence in all dealings with our customers, 
suppliers, bus iness partners, and with each other. All Solitons are expected to uphold these Core Values of 
our company.  
Solitons are encouraged to approach the management team for confidential discussions in case of any 
difference in opinion with the established pract ices or if we become aware of any unethical practice

F. Working Hours  
a) Administrative team is expected to follow the timings from 9:00AM - 6:00PM from Monday to Friday   
 b) Solitons in non -administrative roles are eligible to avail the flexible work time policy, and choose a 
work time between 7:00 AM to 7:00 PM for a period of 9 hours. The 9th hour is dedicated to learning, 
mentoring and organization wide activities.  
c) Let us ensure that we are available for all relevant customer meetings, team meetings and  
interactions.  
d) Solitons are encouraged to stop official work latest by 7:00 PM and pursue other activities like 
sports, exercise, or learning, unless there is a scheduled meeting with a customer.  
e) Any work carried out beyond 7:00 PM should be informed to the Team Lead and the details should 
be filled in the Time Sheet. This is to ensure that the Team Lead and the Company are able to take 
steps to bring down the workload when such occurrences become frequent.  
f) All Solitons should ensure that their Time Shee ts are filled on a weekly basis. Detailed procedures 
will be provided by the Team Lead.  
g) Any permission for time off during the office hours should be communicated via phone or email to 
the Team Lead. These hours need to be compensated within the week, so that the expected number 
of working hours is logged by the end of the week.

G. Environment, Health & Safety Policy [Applicable for India Solitons ]  
We encourage all Solitons to be environmentally conscious and to follow these guidelines:  
a) Save energy by switching off ACs, fans, lights and other electrical appliances when not required.  
b) Be conservative in the use of water in the pantry and in restrooms . Close any unused running taps 
and report leakages to the Admin Team immediately.  
c) Avoid printing documents unless absolutely necessary. When acceptable, use the available stack 
of one -sided sheets for printing.  
d) Any e -waste that is generated has to be di sposed of responsibly. Handover any e -waste (failed 
PCBs, computer accessories, equipment etc.) to the IT team for safe disposal through Eco 
Management companies.  
- Important Note : Equipment failures should also be reported to the purchase team to first 
check for warranty and insurance procedures before they are approved for disposal.  
e) Soliton encourages the use of non -polluting modes of transport such as cycles, by providing 50% 
reimbursement (up to Rs. 2,000) on the purchase cost of cycles.  
f) A first -aid kit is available for use in the pantry area in both the Bangalore and the Coimbatore offices. 
A dormitory is also available within the office for Solitons to take rest in case of sickness.

G. Environment, Health & Safety Policy [Applicable for India Solitons ]  
g) Soliton Admin Team conducts Emergency Evacuation training on a reg ular basis to ensure that all 
Solitons are aware of emergency response procedures and are sufficiently prepared in case of 
disasters. All Solitons have to make themselves available for such trainings. Those willing, can also 
be a part of the Emergency Resp onse Team to step -up and provide guidance to all in times of 
emergency. Those interested may contact Vinod for further information. The details of Soliton 
Emergency Response Team, Emergency Contact Numbers of Local Authorities and Emergency 
Evacuation Rout e is permanently displayed on the office notice board.  
h) Soliton has installed necessary fire detection and suppression systems (smoke detectors, 
sprinklers, fire extinguishers) to identify and avert fire hazards. Emergency Exit Signage are 
prominently plac ed within the building.

1. Privilege Leave (PL)
