c) Intervening weekly offs and National/ Festival holidays will not be included in calculating the number 
of days of PL availed.   
d) However, if a Soliton is on leave without pay, holid ays or weekly off days before or after such leave 
will be treated as Loss of Pay days.   
e) PL should be availed preferably with prior approval of the authorized Project Manager/ Leader   
f) Un-availed PLs, if any, up to a maximum of 30 days can be carried forwa rd to the next calendar 
year. Any accrued PLs, in excess of 30 days, will get lapsed at the end of the calendar year.    
 g) Accrued PLs, if any, up to a maximum of 30 days can be encashed at the time of retirement/ 
separation from the company.   
h) Leave encashme nt is calculated based on the last drawn Base salary using the formula (Monthly 
Basic Salary / 26 * Number of leaves being encashed). The Monthly Gross Salary comprises the 
following components - Basic, Dearness Allowance and Basket of Allowances. The numb er 26 is 
the number of working days in a month, assumed as standard for all months in a year, for the 
purpose of computation of Leave Encashment.   
i) Leave encashment will be processed along with full and final settlement. Such payments shall be 
governed by the Income Tax Act and applicable tax liability should be borne by the Soliton being 
relieved.

2. Sick Leave (SL)    
a) Solitons are entitled to 12 days of Sick Leave in a calendar year, credited at the beginning of 
each year.   
b) This leave can be availed on medical grounds only.   
c) For new joiners, SL credit will be prorated to the number of days remaining in the year, based  
on their date of joining. Any fraction will be rounded off to half -a-day.    
d) SL can neither be carried forward to the next calendar year, nor encashed at the time of 
retirement/ separation. The balance SL will lapse at the end of the calendar year.

3. Maternity Leave (ML)    
a) Expecting women Solitons, who have put in a minimum of 80 days of service, in the past 12 
months, in the organization, are entitled to 26 calendar weeks of paid maternity leave, for up to 
two live births during the woman Solit on’s service with the company.   
b) The twenty -six (26) calendar weeks are inclusive of National/ Festival holidays.   
c) During the loss of pay period/Maternity break, any types of leave will not be granted.  
d) ML can be availed starting 8 weeks before expected date of delivery.   
e) Post return to work from ML, the new mother can avail flexible working hours for 3 months at 
full pay, provided she is able to meet the requirement of 45 hours of work, per week, for every 
week in a given month.   
f) ML cannot be accumulated or availed in instalments and is not encashable under any 
circumstance.   
g) 12 weeks’ paid maternity leave is applic able for the third or later child, as per the prevailing 
Maternity Act (2016).   
h) In case of adoption, if the age of the child is less than 6 months, the adopting mother is entitled 
to 12 weeks’ paid maternity leave. Commissioning mothers are also eligible for 12 weeks’ paid 
maternity leave.   
i) In case of miscarriage, a woman Soliton shall, on production of proof as may be prescribed by 
a medical practitioner (Form -B), be entitled to leave with pay, for a period of 6 weeks 
immediately following the day of the  miscarriage. The requirement of proof and completion of 
Form -B is a mandatory requirement as per the Indian Government’s Maternity Act. ML will not 
be applicable in this case.   
j) The woman Soliton, who avails ML, undertakes to not take up alternate employm ent and/ or 
engage in any work elsewhere, with or without pay, during the period she is on ML.

4. Paternity Leave (PTL)  
a) Solitons are entitled to PTL of 15 working days per childbirth. Leaves are credited at the 
beginning of every calendar year aft er the completion of 1 year.   
b) For new joiners, PTL credit will be credited upon confirmation.    
 c) PTL is not encashable.

5. Bereavement Leave  
The Bereavement Leave is a paid time off intended to support Solitons during the loss of an 
immediate family member. We trust that this profoundly essential framework will offer every Soliton 
with the necessary time to mourn their loss, be part in essentia l rituals & formalities, while being 
surrounded by their loved ones.   
Details on the policy are given here.    
No. of leaves: Upto 3 weeks (15 working days)   
Eligibility:  Applicable for all Solitons, across all locations   
Immediate family members refer to:   
o  Parents & Parents in -
law o  Spouse & Kids  o 
 Siblings (own)

6. National/ Festival Holidays    
a) The company shall announce a maximum of 10 National/ Festival holidays in a year based on 
the mandatory holidays prescribed by the Central/ State government and other social/ religious 
considerations.   
b) List of National/ Festival Holidays will be published  in December every year, for the upcoming 
calendar year.

7. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
a) Solitons, based on their superior work performance, at the discretion of the Manager and/ or 
Sr. Leadership, can avail LwoP for up to 1 year, for personal reaso ns of an exigent and 
demanding nature.   
b) To avail of this leave benefit, a Soliton should have been in continuous service with the 
Company for a minimum of 2 years.   
c) The leave benefit would be calculated as 1 year of LwoP for every completed 2 years’ tenu re 
in Soliton. ‘Completed tenure’ refers to working full time in any of the Soliton offices or at client 
site.   
d) LwoP could be availed for personal reasons like extended leave for childcare, over and above 
the benefits under ML Policy, emergency situations  in the family or travel with spouse to onsite 
locations (spouse could be working with other companies), or higher education, or any other 
unplanned and emergency personal situation. Specific approval needs to be taken from The 
People Team and Delivery Hea d for availing this benefit.   
e) New role for Solitons returning to work post completion of LwoP, will be determined based on 
available, and relevant, openings at that point in time.

7. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
f) Increment and Promotion: In case a salary review or a promotion exercise is conducted during 
the period of absence of the Soliton, the individual would not be eligible for either an increment 
or a promotion in that particular cycle.   
g) Provident Fund: The Company’s contribution towards the Employees Provident Fund, for 
eligible Solitons, would cease for this period. As the PF contribution is calculated on Basic 
salary, it will not be paid for the duration when there is no salary payout for the individual.    
 h) Gratuity: The duration of LwoP would be considered for the payment of Gra tuity, in line with the 
conditions for the same, as laid down by the Payment of Gratuity Act. Since such leave is 
considered as period of “continuous service”, as per the Act, Gratuity will accrue for the whole 
period.   
i) PL eligibility: The period in which  the Soliton avails this benefit would not be considered as 
continuous service to the Company for the purpose of privilege leave entitlement, i.e. PL will 
not be credited for the period the Soliton is on LwoP.   
j) Insurance: For the period of LwoP, the Solit on would continue to be covered under the 
Company’s Insurance Policy.

7. Leave without Pay (LwoP)    
k) LwoP includes weekends and any declared National/ Festival holidays.   
l) LwoP cannot be accumulated or carried forward, under any circumstance.

8. Compensatory Off (Comp off)    
a) If a Soliton is required to work, on an important work assignment on a declared holiday/ weekly -
off day, s/he would be eligible to apply for Comp off on any other working day.   
b) Prior approval is required from the Project Manager/ Lead to work on Nationa l holidays/ 
declared holidays/ weekly off days.   
c) Comp off can be granted only if a Soliton has attended work in person, either in office or at 
onsite. It is also  extended to Solitons, who have worked from home, on the given day with prior 
intimation.   
d) The credited Comp off has to be availed within a period of 90 days from the date he/she worked.   
e) Comp offs, when not availed within the stipulated time period, will get lapsed. It cannot be 
carried forward or accumulated under any circumstance.

9. Privilege Leave for Probationers    
During the probation period, a maximum of 2 days of Privilege Leave may be availed during the 
first 3 months and another 4 days of Privilege Leave during the remaining period of 3 months.

10. Leave for Solitons on part/ flexi time work arrangements:    
Solitons on part/flexi -time work arrangements are entitled to National/ Festival Holidays, as 
declared by the company every year. The standard Leave Policy is applicable on a pro -rata basis 
to Solitons who avail the part time working mode on a fixed proportion basis. Those on an hourly 
pay will not have any paid leave eligibility.

11. Leave for Solitons based in work locations outside India:    
Solitons based in work locations outside Indi a would be governed by the applicable laws and 
required legal compliance in the each host country.

 c) ML cannot be accumulated or availed in instalments and is not encashable under any

years of experience.

5. Leave on Compensation (LoC)  
a) Solitons can avail the leave of compensation only for the days already worked, with prior

b) LoC can be availed for working on any Saturday/Sunday/declared holiday.  
c) LoC duly approved by the manager / Equivalent Authority should be submitted along with the 
leave application.

6. Medical leave  
Solitons with atleast  1 year of experience are entitled to unpaid Medical leave each year for any of 
the following reasons. The duration of the unpaid leave will need to be discussed with and approved 
by the reporting manager,   
a. To care for an immediate family member (i.e., sp ouse, child, or parent) with a serious health 
condition;   
b. To take medical leave when Soliton is unable to work because of a serious health condition.

Procedure for availing Leave  
a) Solitons have to apply for leaves through the HRMS system (Greyt HR) well in advance.   
b) In case of emergencies, the leave details can be updated in the system upon returning to duty. 
This has to be done on the day of returning.  
c) The notice period recommended for planned leave is two weeks in advance. In general, please 
provide as much advance notice as possible.

4. Training & Development Policy  
At Soliton, Training & Development is viewed as the impartation of industry -specific knowledge and skills 
with the aim to improve productivity, performance and provide better value to our customers. It brings in the 
culture of continuous learning with flex ibility to choose the training program as per one’s interest and 
aspiration.  
Design of any Training & Development program in the fiscal year will be preceded by a thorough Needs 
Assessment. The Needs Assessment will help to diagnose problems and gaps at t he organization level. 
The design and subsequent execution of training and development programs will address those lacks / 
needs of Solitons so that they will be better equipped to perform effectively and generate value for 
customers.  
The primary method o f assessing needs at Soliton will be through analysis of the following: a. 
Team Delight feedback  
b. Customer Delight feedback  
c. Great Place to Work (GPW) Survey  
d. Exit interviews  
e. Feedback from performance appraisal discussions  
f. Feedback from team members / project leads  
g. PMO project performance information

General T& D Programs at Soliton   
EXCEL at Soliton   
Soliton interns go through an intensive training program, EXCEL at Soliton  during the first two and half 
months of their employment with Soliton, which includes competency based behavioral, soft skills and 
communication training. For 15 days, after the com pletion of the program, interns will undergo work specific 
training based on the performance expectation of the project to which the interns are assigned.  
Engineers may sometimes, go through EXCEL at Soliton  program during the internship period. Based on 
the extent of training completed during the internship, engineers may be excluded from all or part of the 
post-joining TIPS.

Professional Excellence Program for Solitons (PEPS)   
Soliton organizes two separate Professional Excellence Program for Solitons  (PEPS) annually, one for 
Senior Project Engineers and another program for Project Leads. The program enables engineers to grow 
to the next level of their career by preparing them for the opportunity to take on higher responsibilities as 
they jointly discu ss strategies and address any concerns in the current work model.

Knowledge Sharing Sessions (KSS)  
Knowledge Sharing Sessions (KSS) conducted on a weekly basis for 1 hour at the project team level, allows 
the presenter to share project learnings, indus try best practices, technology and tools with all.

Support for Continuous Development   
NI Certification Programs   
We will provide 100% sponsorship for Solitons to complete NI Certification programs. It will be the 
responsibility of Project Managers to recommend individuals to opt in for the program at the appropriate 
time in their career.  
The People Team will facilit ate a pre -assessment in consultation with the delivery team to assess the 
readiness of Solitons to undergo the certification program.  Solitons who clear the pre -assessment will be 
eligible to undergo the certification .  
Other Certification Programs   
Eligibility: Minimum of 3 years’ service in the company with performance rating of 4 or above.   
For Solitons with 3 years or more tenure in the company, we will provide reimbursement up to 50% of the 
fee incurred after successful completion of the certificati on with maximum limit of Rs.1 lakh for India Solitons 
and 3750 USD for US Solitons.  
Every 6 months, The People Team will share the list of sponsored certification programs and invite 
applications. The number of Solitons who can avail of the sponsorships f or each certification will be 
mentioned in the invite.  
The list of courses eligible for such sponsorship will be updated / notified by The People Team in consultation 
with the Head of Delivery from time to time.   
The 50% of claimed/reimbursed amount has t o be paid back if the concerned Soliton resigns within 2 
years from the date of reimbursement and 100% has to be paid back if he/she resigns within 1 year.

Reimbursement process   
The certification/ course fee has to be paid by the Soliton and subject to successful completion of the course, 
he/she can apply for reimbursement of the fee.  
The reimbursement claim has to  be submitted to People team, along with the invoice or paid receipt and 
copy of the completion certificate.

Corporate Training Programs   
Leadership and general management programs that will help in continuous development of managerial 
skills, business skills and leadership skills will be explored and factored by L&D team as part of their 
planning and budgeting exercise.
5. Benefits

A. Medical Insurance -   
India Solitons  
All Solitons from the date of joining are covered under Mediclaim policy. It is a floater Family Mediclaim  
Policy with sum assured is Rs. 2,00,000/ - for Solitons up to PLs and Rs.3,00,000/ - for Managers and above 
(Spouse, kids and dependent parents / Pare nts-in-laws).  
a) The company will pay the entire premium for the Soliton, spouse and kids. For coverage of parents/ 
parents -in-law, the company will contribute 50% of the premium and the remaining 50% to be borne 
by the Soliton.  
b) Siblings will NOT be cover ed under this policy.  
c) Mediclaim policy will cover the expenses incurred on hospitalization above 24hrs. Doctor consulting 
fees, medicines with hospital charges can be claimed.  
d) The policy covers all existing diseases like diabetes, BP, cataract, etc. exce pt plastic surgery.  
e) Mediclaim policy covers maternity benefits restricted to first 2 children only – with a per family limit 
of Rs.60,000/ - in case of caesarean and Rs.50,000/ - for normal delivery. The baby is covered from 
Day 1.  
f) On account of any promot ion to the next level, the sum assured will be changed only at the time of 
policy renewal, and not at the time of promotion.

Medical insurance  
US Solitons  
It is optional for people to choose between company provided group insurance and insurance av ailable in 
the marketplace. If after comparing rates and features, the person chooses not to participate in the company 
group plan, then the entire CTC would be take home pay subject to normal withholding. If they choose to 
participate in the company group  plan, the CTC and the premium amount will be taken into consideration 
to arrive at the take -home pay subject to normal holding.

B. Accidental coverage [Applicable for India Solitons]   
a) All Solitons (Except family members) are covered under an Accident insurance.  
b) Accident insurance sum assured is Rs.5L for PEs, 10L for SPE, 15L for PL & 20L for Managers & 
above levels.   
c) Flat Rs. 15000 Accidental claim max or actual both IPD/OPD not link ed to claim.   
d) Covers up to 1% of the sum insured or Rs.10,000 or actual salary per week up to 104 weeks for 
long absence from work due to injury.   
Please refer to the Mediclaim guideline  for more details on Mediclaim & Accidental Coverage.  
Exclu sion: Interns, Trainees & People on Contract are not eligible to be covered under this Mediclaim  & 
Accidental Coverage.

C. Company Loan  
Eligibility : Loans would be available to all confirmed Solitons who are in good  standing and not under 
probation. For new Solitons in probation, a loan may be availed only for paying the rent advance and 
upto one month's salary.  
Loan Amount : The amount of loan that a Soliton can avail is based on the years of  experience at Soliton.  
If the completed years of experience is ‘n’, a Soliton can avail a loan of up to ‘n’ month’s salary up to a 
maximum of 5 month’s salary. For Solitons with over 5 years of experience, the maximum available loan 
is 5 month’s salary.

• Interest for India Solitons   
Based on the purpose of the loans, the loans will have two categories – Emergency and 
NonEmergency loans. A nominal interest of 5% per annum on the outstanding balance would be 
charged for all emergency loans, except for people who earn less th an Rs. 10,000 per month.   
A nominal interest of 10% per annum on the outstanding balance would be charged for all nonemergency 
loans, except for people who earn less than Rs. 10,000 per month.

• Interest for US Solitons   
The interest rate for loans t o US Solitons is governed by guidelines published by the IRS. Please contact 
People Team for further details.

Repayment Duration:  
A loan would be repayable in equated monthly installments within 12  months from the date of 
disbursement. For Solitons wit h over 2 years of experience at Soliton, the repayment period can be 
extended to 18 months based on need.

Reason for loan :  
The reason for availing loan has to be provided. This is necessary to prioritize  utilization of available funds.

Additional Loans:  
 A new loan may be availed only 3 months after full repayment of an existing  loan.  
Availability:  
 All loan disbursements are subject to the availability of funds and it may take up to  4 weeks to disburse 
funds from the time of loan approval.  
Documentation:  
A loan agreement has to be signed by everyone availing loan, confirming that  they will continue their 
employment in Soliton until the loan is fully repaid.

E. Part Time Work Mode Policy  
Part time work mode means to work for a feas ible number of hours at home or office or combination of both. 
But Solitons have to make sure the tasks and responsibilities are fulfilled. Part time work mode is for a 
specified duration only.  
a) Approval of a request to avail part time work mode for a spec ified duration is subject to the joint 
discretion of the concerned Department Head and the Manager - People Team. This decision will 
be based on the nature of work carried out by the Soliton in question.  
b) Salary claimed by a Soliton availing part time work  mode, is based on the number of hours of work 
put in for the month.  
c) The standard Leave Policy is applicable on a pro -rata basis to Solitons who avail the part time 
working mode on a fixed proportion basis. Those on an hourly pay will not have any paid le ave 
eligibility.

F. Work from Home  
Working from home is applicable for below 2 scenarios:  
a) Emergency Situation : When there is an urgent requirement or emergency where we are required 
to be at home either to take care of children or care for any other individual who is sick at home 
and where we feel we can still manage our entire day’s work.  
b) Long term Requirement:  This option is also granted for engineers who are relocating for the reasons 
of marriage, post maternity to take care of newborn or any unavoidable dependency. The WFH is 
typically approved for Solitons who have demonstrated high work ethic and performanc e. This will 
be determined by the concerned manager in discussion with the Soliton.

7. Team Outing Policy   
Soliton truly appreciates the ha rd work and dedication put in by every Soliton. All Solitons are encouraged 
to go on annual trips/ lunch or dinner outings/ movies or other fun activities, as a team, to bond with fellow 
colleagues, to unwind and rejuvenate.   
1) Team Outing  
Budget allocated for:  
• India Solitons : Rs. 1200/ - per Soliton per term , for all expenses aggregated.   
• US Solitons: 50 USD per Soliton per term, for all expenses aggregated.   
   The budget allocation will be term -
wise, as below:    
Term 1 : April to Ju ly   
Term 2 : August to November   
Term 3 : December to March

Process of Team Outing  
a) Solitons must check the availability of budget before planning for and/ or incurring the expense.   
 b) The Project Manager would be in -charge of the trip. Responsibility for limiting expenses within 
the budget, selection of location, ensuring the safety of the team, etc., would rest with the 
Project Manager.   
c) After the outing, original bills need to be submitted for all expenses including conveyance, along 
with the approved team outing claim  form, to the Accounts team for verification and approval 
of claims.  
d) Reimbursement will be made based on the actual number of attendees only and will not exceed 
the budget allo cated for the outing. Any additional spending, over and above the allocated 
budget, would need to be borne by the touring Solitons. Reimbursement of expenses will be 
towards food, non -alcoholic beverages, conveyance within or outside city limits and any ot her 
arrangements considered essential for conducting the team outing.   
e) Soliton safety and security must be accorded top priority, while planning a team outing. Care 
should be taken to avoid venues prone to accidents or pose possible risk to human life. An y 
outing organized at/ near such locations would be the responsibility of the individual Soliton

Process of Team Outing  
and their respective Manager(s) and the company undertakes no responsibility in the event of 
any mishap.   
f) Care should also be taken to not extend the team o uting to odd hours, to avoid exposing 
Solitons to risks of any sort.    
We strongly encourage teams to utilize the budget every term. However, in rare cases of project 
exigencies, for teams that are unable to take time for team outings in a term, the budget may be carried 
forward to the subsequent term, based on pre -approval f rom the Delivery Head and People Team 
Manager. Upon approval, cumulative budget for two terms may be used for the outing.    
Every Soliton’s decision to participate in a team outing is purely voluntary. No individual shall be compelled 
to participate in an outing, against their interest.   
Usage of company vehicles for team outing is not permitted; the limit specified is inclu sive of budget towards 
conveyance expenses. Teams may rent a cab/ hire a private vehicle or use their own vehicle(s) for 
conveyance. Necessary care and precautions need to be always taken, to avoid any incident/mishap during 
travel.

8.  Roles a nd Responsibilities - Project Management Team  [Applicable for India 
Solitons]

Project Manager (SPM/ PM)   
Project Manager has the overall accountability of the project(s) managed. The PM generates forecasts, 
removes obstacles, ensures alignment with organizational strategy, champions the team and manages 
cross -functional project interfaces to ensure that the p roject delivers the agreed business outcomes.  
Below are the broad responsibilities of a PM:  
a) Manages a team size of about 10 -20 engineers (could be smaller or larger)  
b) Maximize Team Delight working closely with HR Business Partners  
• Ensure that each  member’s interest is aligned to their work  
• Ensure that each member is learning and growing  
• Ensure that the workload and challenge is at the right level  
• Ensure that each member feels respected and appreciated  
• Ensure that the team members are enjoying t heir work  
c) Maximize Billable Utilization of the team (actual billing/ billing capacity)  
• Organize the team to efficiently handle the project inflow from the Accounts that the team 
services working closely with the PMO team.  
• Assign team members to the pr ojects based on complexity and risk involved

Project Manager (SPM/ PM)   
• Get involved with the sales and proposal effort to understand the risks, ensure that the projects 
are estimated and quoted correctly, and the commitments are made considering all the 
important factors.  
d) Monitor, Analyse and Report key metrics  
• Weekly: RHYTHM report for the team  
• Billable Utilization of the team  
• Average Effort and Maximum Effort  
e) Highlight excess capacity or capacity constraint  
f) Identify and highlight the risk of any kind of disruption  
• Monthly: Revenue, IP, Training Material generated by the team along with the summary of the 
month  
• Quarterly: Review which includes the analysis of profitability (Billable Utilization) by type of 
project and Soliton Delight achieved by the team + Next quarter plan  
g) Performance Management and Leadership Development  
• Set quarterly goals (KRAs) for each of the team members

Project Manager (SPM/ PM)   
• Provide coaching and mentoring, with support from HR, to develop the next set  of PMs  
• Provide guidance on career development for the team members  
h) Recruitment and Training  
• Recruit for the team either internally or laterally in a timely manner based on forecasts from the 
Account Managers  
• Organize training for new and existing team members in a timely manner to ensure that they are 
productive in the projects   
 k) IP, Traini ng Material, Process Development    
• Identify and develop IP that can be used to increase the non -linear revenue of own Team and other 
teams  
• Develop training material for own team and also share with other teams  
• Develop and implement the processes for eff ective team management  
Based on the nature and size of the project, the PM may manage one or more projects.

Project Owner   
Project Owner (PO) identifies/ understands the project’s objectives, scope and activities that will deliver the 
desired r esults. PO is responsible for collecting all the requirements of the project and completing the same 
within an established timeline and budget.  
Below are the broad responsibilities of a Project Owner:  
a) #1 is Customer Delight  
• Overall responsibility for customer success  
• Main point of contact for the project for the customer  
• Ensure timely and complete written and verbal communication to the cu stomer to report on 
progress and challenges, if any and how they are being addressed.  
b) #2 is Team Delight (scope of team management will vary based on level of PO)  
• Team has to feel like they are on a wonderful adventure. That they are enjoying, being encouraged 
to improve, and learning from the experience. And they should feel appreciated for the efforts that 
they are taking, and the success that they are bringing.  
c) #3 is Project Profitability  
• The project owner has to ensure that the customer feel s like they are getting great value while 
ensuring that the project is profitable for Soliton. Ensuring this balance is a very important part of 
the job and the Project Owner has to escalate and seek advice when necessary.  
• Budget slips/ red flags to be raised by taking the right judgmental call  
d) Monitor, Analyse and Report the key metrics  
• Weekly: RHYTHM Reports  
• End of each Sprint: Retrospective Report  
• End of Project: Project Retrospective Report, Soliton Delight achieved, and any IP, case study, 
training material, and process improvements to be generated

Architect   
An Architect provides technical leadership and support to development teams by way  of designing functional 
technology solutions and managing complex programs (overseeing development and implementation). An 
Architect is an excellent communicator, who is able to translate complex technical requirements into 
functional architecture.  
 Below are the broad responsibilities of a Technical Architect:  
a) #1 is Provide Technical Inputs and Reviews for Products and Projects  
• Ensure that the right design/ architecture is chosen and implemented correctly  
• Assess technical risks and provide mitig ation plans  
• Ensure that the right tools and development practices are used  
• Provide troubleshooting assistance to ensure best progress  
b) #2 is Provide Technical Depth and Breadth  
• Have enough Breadth with exposure to multiple technology areas and  make critical decisions on 
technology choices.  
• Have enough depth  to understand and teach technical concepts to peer groups.  
• Have strong grasp of software engineering practices.

Architect   
c) #3 is  Win New Business through Technical Strength  
• Make technical presentations to customers to help sales team win projects  
• Assess the technical risks in project proposals and propose risk mitigation solutions  
• Provide assistance to estimate work correctly so the right commitments are made  
• Provide inputs to influence the business strategy based on internal technical strengths and 
developments going on outside the company.  
d) #4 is Ensure Team is Best Trained and Equipped to handle the work  
• Keep abreast  of the relevant advances in the relevant fields  
• Evangelize and promote best practices  
• Curate/ Develop and make available the most effective training material for the team to learn and 
assess their level of expertise (through certification tests)  
• Deliver the training in group or 1 -1 settings to bring up the capabilities of the team to world -class 
levels  
e) Responsible for furthering the company’s technical competence by providing thought leadership and 
mentorship, across BUs/ Teams/ Specializations, at the Company level.

9. Soliton Recognition Framework  
Objective    
The objective of the program is to drive a culture of recognition at Soliton.   
Eligibility    
Applicable to all Solitons, based in offices in India as well as overseas locations.   
Framework    
 Soliton Recognition Framework is based on a 3 -tiered approach comprising, Person to Person recognition, 
awards at the Business Unit level and awards at the Organization level.   
Award Types

B.  Org level recognition  
Designed to recognize outstanding work done by individuals and/ or teams, by going above and beyond the 
normal performance and expectations of their respective roles in the company.  
Excellence Award Types   
• Team Player of the year  – The individual who everyone loves to work with, because he/she 
inspires us to do better and is just so impressive!  
• Innovator Of The Year  – The individual who is always brimming with new ideas and solutions and 
has even made clients go ‘Wow”!  
• Accelerator of the Year - This individual or team made significant contributions to the company by 
developing the most useful tools, processes, systems or training  
• Social Impact Champion  – This award recognizes employees who went the extra mile and 
contributed to CSR initiatives that h ave had a positive impact on society or helped address a social 
issue and improved the lives of many  
• Mentoring Champion  - A Soliton who invests time in coaching/guiding and contributes to the 
success of the mentee.  
• Rookie Of The Year  – The rookie from Ne w Batch who is just awesome and stands out because 
he/she is a trendsetter in the batch!  
• Team of the Year  - The team that provided stellar customer experience with demonstrated 
evidence of people, processes, and technology coming together seamlessly   
• Soliton of The Year  – The individual who has undoubtedly made the biggest difference, impacting 
and inspiring  many within Soliton!  
Criteria : Refer Appendix C  for criteria for each award

Process for Excellence Awards  
a) Winners are selected through a two -level peer voting process.  
b) People Team would centrally manage the process.  
• Nomination: Every individual nominates a fellow Soliton/ team, either within or outside immediate 
team/ BU, for each award category. Self -nomination is also encouraged.  
• Compilation: The awards committee com piles the list of nominations received for each category 
and sends the list, along with a citation to all Solitons for their voting.  
• Voting: Solitons read the citations/ seek more information by talking to concerned people before 
casting their votes.  
• Selection: The awards committee, comprising the Soliton Leadership team, then tallies the votes & 
selects the recipient(s) of each award. The Leadership team is also eligible to vote for all awards.  
c) Winners are recognized, at the Annual Soliton Day event, wi th Certificate, Plaque and Cash Awards.

Fun Awards  
In addition to all the above categories of Awards, “fun” awards are designed to share some lighter moments 
at the company. Various fun categories are decided and announced prior to the annual day e vent; winners 
are decided following a 2 -level peer voting process.  
APPENDIX B  
Star Soliton and Star Team Award definitions

B1. Definition of Customer Delight  
a) Looking at the world from the customer’s point of view - doing things that are right,  to maximise value 
for the customer.  
b) Understand Customers’ problem areas better - ask questions, challenge status quo, adopt 
unconventional ways of problem solving.  
c) Build trusted relationships with key stakeholders, which results in a win -win situation for Customer and 
Soliton.  
d) Measurement criteria: One or more of the following - Appreciation/ Testimonial from client, Testimonial 
from Manager, Client Satisfaction Score > 4.

B2. Definition of Team Delight  
a) Takes initiatives to conduct and manage various activities in the team regularly to ensure:  
• Team members’ interest is aligned to their work  
• Team members enjoy their work - understand the significance, have th e required autonomy, and 
are challenged to  the right level  
• Team members feel respected, appreciated, coached, and challenged so that they are growing as 
fast as they can  
b) Listens to the team members with intent; responds empathetically  
c) Builds trusting relationship with team members  
d) Provides direction and inputs to raise the performance for the team  
e) Measurement criteria: Team Delight Score, Manager feedback, HRBP feedback

B3. Description of Company Values   
B3.1. Integrity  
Open and forthright in Communication  
a) We follow an “open” culture of communication based on trust in one another. We sp eak our mind while 
being respectful and courteous. We do not have “hidden” agendas when dealing with others; our 
intentions are clearly spelt out.  
b) We do not lie. We do everything possible to gain a reputation with all stakeholders (investors, 
customers, p artners, and vendors) for setting and meeting the highest levels of integrity.  
c) We are true to ourselves and we are comfortable with who we are. We genuinely encourage and respect 
individuality and diversity as long as they are consistent with our core val ues and culture.  
d) We know that we are not perfect and we don't act like we are. We own up to our mistakes boldly and 
put in serious effort to ensure that we don’t repeat it and we share our experience and learning openly 
so that others don’t make the sam e mistake either.  
e) We speak our mind on all matters affecting the company and particularly on matters that affect our work. 
If we are discontented about anything, we do not spread this discontent around, but work with urgency 
to get it resolved to our satisfaction by speakin g to those who are able to bring about a positive outcome 
or solution.  
f) We also understand that if after sufficient discussions we find that our views are significantly at odds 
with the culture of the company and we do not believe that they are resolvabl e, we should give the 
company notice about our intention to leave rather than continue to work with dissatisfaction. We know 
that Soliton will respect us for this and negotiate a reasonable timeframe for the transition out of the 
company and provide a fair  and objective reference to a prospective employer while explaining the 
reason for the departure.

B3.2 Respectful and Caring  
a) We treat everybody in Soliton and outside with respect, irrespective of their role and responsibility in 
the company or in society. We have zero tolerance for disrespect.  
b) Our actions are guided by what is in the best interest of each individual Soliton as well as all of us 
together. We share a world -view that says “what is in the best interest of all of us is what is in my best 
interest”. It is not an “or” view but an “and” view.  
c) Our policies are not rules or laws but guidelines. When they  do not make sense in a situation, we use 
our judgment to take decisions that feel right to us. If such a decision involves substantia l cost to the 
company we ensure that we get our judgment validated by one or more Solitons. Again we use our best 
judgment about who to contact for validation.  
d) We are sensitive to the feelings of others and ensure that we immediately correct any behavio r that is 
deemed by others as insensitive or rude. When we find ourselves in situations where we feel that 
somebody is being unusually sensitive and easily hurt, we deal with this matter with sensitivity and 
understanding to bring about a change in the out look of that person by taking into confidence somebody 
who they trust.  
e) For individuals who lead/ supervise teams: We team leaders know that we are the first level HR

B3.2 Respectful and Caring  
Managers for our teams. We ensure that each team member is happy and productive, and in terpersonal 
relations are conducive for effective teamwork. We try to inspire through example, so that each member  
 in our team learns to balance their work and family/ personal time in a way that they are most 
comfortable.  
f) Soliton gives priority to comm itments given to customers and there is a lot of emphasis on high quality 
output delivered on time, but this is never at the cost of the wellbeing of anybody. Each person is asked 
to stretch only as much as they choose to. When we see that somebody needs h elp, we readily step in 
to help and ensure that customer commitments are met.  
g) We take pride in our individual abilities and accomplishments, but we temper it with the humility that 
comes from the knowledge that what we can do as a team far outweighs anything that we can do 
individually. We abhor any display of arrogance.

B3.3. Excellence  
a) We give our 100% in each and every activity we do and we are always looking for ways to beat our 
previous best performance.  
b) We demonstrate our excellence, not by showing ourselves as perfect or even as better than others, but 
through our const ant urge to find ways to improve.  
c) We admire results gained from hard work combined with hard thinking more than results obtained from 
just one’s innate intelligence or capabilities.  
d) We  do not require any supervision because we are driven by an internal sense of duty and responsibility 
that demands that we do our very best in each and every task that impacts Soliton’s success.  
e) We especially understand that customer satisfaction is key to our success and we instinctively act like 
an owner of Soliton by as suming any responsibility necessary and doing our best to ensure our 
customer’s success.  
f) We are active self -learners.  To keep improving, we are always on the lookout for excellence in all forms;  
to be inspired and learn from it.  
g) We understand that exce llence does not guarantee success but it maximizes our probability for 
success. We boldly take on important initiatives even when the odds are against us. We demonstrate 
excellence by doing everything possible to succeed in the initiative while capturing a ll the learning from 
the experience for the success of our future initiatives.  
h) We do not cover -up any weak -links in our work for any reason,  or to “showcase” it as being excellent. 
We will disclose any weak -link that is not corrected at the time of deliv ery, and we will not rest until it is. 
We understand that there can be no excellence without integrity. B4. Description of Leadership 
Principles - TOWOD

a)  TOWOD -Practice Radical Transparency  
• Be open and honest in expressing our opinion with customers and people. But learn how to do it 
constructively before practicing it, especially with customers.  
• Promote healthy debates. Lack of debate = Lack of trust.

b)  TOWOD -Take Ownership. Great Leaders = Great Teams  
• Always work towards the best interest of the team. Not towards self and/ or individual gains.  
• Be responsible for all good & bad decisions. When things  do not go well, step up and take 
accountability of it; whe n they succeed, step back and give credit to the team.  
• We get OUT of the team, what we put INTO it. When people perform below expectations, mentor 
them with full faith. If it  does not work, find a better place for them.

c)  TOWOD -Play to Win  
• Commit t o personal growth and behavioral changes. Have a growth mindset and find ways to keep 
improving. Do not settle for less than what we want to see happen.  
• Larger the problems, work more aggressively to address it. Do not ignore and settle for defeat. 
Always  search for and find ways to get to Win -Win rather than Win -Lose or Lose -Win.

d)  TOWOD -One Soliton One Team  
• Refrain from creating silos and promote cross team collaboration. Silos are created when one team 
is not interested in another team’s activitie s.  
• Overall Company objective is of higher priority than individual and team priority: Company>Team 
>Individual  
• Managers are part of 2 teams: the team that reports to them and the peer group of all Managers.

e)  TOWOD -Discipline  
• Our thoughts, action s and speech should be always aligned.  
• We hold ourselves and others to high standards. We point it out when somebody falls short so that 
we keep our standards high. But we do this with humility, knowing that we are not perfect and 
welcoming others to not let us slip either.

10. Feedback Channels  
We foster a culture that encourages open and honest communication across all levels (Peer to Peer, Team 
member to Reporting manager, Solitons to Leadership team, Juniors to Seniors etc). Soliton welcomes all 
types of feedback (general comments, compliments , constructive criticism, and concerns).  
 The aim is to share all observations in a constructive way that helps engage others, encourage Solitons to 
listen to each other’s ideas and solve problems together in a way that drives continuous improvement.  
These guidelines are created to set forth different channels by which all Solitons can effectively voice their 
feedback.  
Guidelines

Solitons can make use of the following channels to provide feedback;  
a) Direct (verbal / email):   
This is the most recommen ded channel for all types of feedback.  
We encourage the leaders to use this channel to give effective feedback to their team members. Team 
members can use this platform to provide feedback to their reporting manager, and it can also be used 
among non -reporting colleagues as well. b) Through a mediator (email):   
In the event where Solitons are not able to share their feedback about their peers / colleagues / seniors / 
juniors / Reporting Manager directly, they can route it through a mediator. Solitons can a lso use this 
channel to share reviews about any Soliton that includes HR team members and Leadership team .  
Such feedback can be sent to feedback@solitontech.com  and it will be routed to HR Manager (Anu 
Antony) and Leadership team members (Ganesh Devaraj  & Arjun Sathiyaseelan) who will help to 
mediate the discussion. Solitons can feel free to write an email directly to any of the leadership team 
members as well.  
c) Anonymous channel (written):   
Solitons can make use of this channel by filling -in the details of their feedback using the following link here.  
Since this channel does not directly align with our culture of open ness, we do not recommend using this 
channel in a normal scenario. But incase  a Soliton feels uncomfortable in disclosing his or her identity 
while sharing the feedback especially about those who are in senior roles, this channel can be used.  
We need to be aware that anonymity can be helpful for bringing an issue to light, but it may not help to 
understand the issue and resolve it. Anonymous feedback takes away the opportunity for people to talk 
things through and  find ways to work better together in the  future.  
If any Soliton wants to address the feedback through a formal channel involving Human Resources, until 
closure, we can send it through the Grievance redressing channel (refer grievance redressal policy for more 
details).

How to give Effect ive Feedback?   
Feedback should be given in a manner that will best help improve performance. Since people respond 
better to information presented in a positive way, feedback should be expressed with the intent to help the  
 person. This is not to say that in formation should be sugar -coated. It must be accurate, factual, and 
complete.  
Here are some guidelines to ensure that the feedback is constructive and our colleagues are more 
receptive;   
   Feedback Formula = Situation + Behaviour + Impact + Next step  
Situation:  
Specify the situation in which we give the feedback. It is important to give our colleague a context with the 
point of time and date to relate to. Let him/her know that we are referring to what happened during the team 
meeting a day before, for  instance and not the presentation three weeks ago.   
Behaviour  
Describe the behaviour. Make sure that we are being clear and objective. Focus on the actions that  the  
colleague took, not his / her personality.  
Impact:

How to give Effect ive Feedback?   
We can make our feedback stronger  by describing the impact of the - demonstrated behaviour. For instance, 
our colleague’s action - could impact one person, a few people, or the whole group. Think of the big picture 
and choose the impact that is most appropriate in each situation.  
The Nex t Step:  
Finally, offer our colleague the next steps that he/she can take. Suggest what he / she could do, to - handle 
it better next time.  
Take Care of the Body Language  
a) When we give the feedback in person, be aware of our body language. Avoid gesture s or a tone that 
might either send recipients into a defensive mode or make them afraid.  
b) Do not raise the voice. It might seem like we are angry. Instead, just share the critical comments and 
help them understand how they can improve. We are not angry, bu t would like  to  share  comments to 
help them improve.  
c) Do not cross our arms. We  do not want to look like we are not going to let them explain their behaviour.  
d) Do not frown. We are not there to judge but to provide support.  
e) Keep a friendly tone and an open body language because we want to create an atmosphere of trust

How to give Effect ive Feedback?   
and openness. That would really help the recipient to take in our feedback.

How to receive f eedback effectively?   
a) Be an active listener. Practice effective listening skills. Encourage the person offering feedback to talk. 
We will learn more about ourself, how others see us, and how others interpret our actions and 
behaviors.  
b) Be respectful. Be aware of the body language, facial expression, and tone. Maintain eye contact and 
be careful not to get defensive (not even crossing our arms). If we disagree, or are upset, or angry, give 
ourself time to calm down before responding. And, when we do, caref ully choose our words; they matter. 
Take it for what it is; that is, feedback we can use to improve our performance. Think on how we can 
improve the behavior, attitude, or situation. Learn from it.  
c) Ask questions. Clarify doubts by asking questions. Be c ertain to ask questions that help us to 
understand the feedback. Ask for examples that support the feedback.   
d) Show appreciation. Express our appreciation regardless of the type of feedback we receive. We can 
expect that at several times during employment , we will receive both positive and negative feedback. 
Saying ‘thank you’ means that we acknowledge the effort that was taken to provide feedback.  
e) Make a decision . Reflect on the feedback and decide the next steps, how are we going to use the 
feedback to further our development. We  do not always have to act on all the feedback that we receive. 
We build our relationship with someone when they feel heard, which is a chieved by our listening, without 
judgement. We would recommend, that we reinforce the value we place on their feedback by circling 
back around and letting them know what we ultimately did.

Processing Feedback   
Once feedback has been received through the 2nd and 3rd channels, it will be assessed for further action.  
If the feedback is a general comment, compliment, concern, or constructive criticism, it will be 
communicated immediately to the person involved. I f the matter requires greater attention, and has some 
level of complication, it will be further discussed at  various levels and communicated to the person involved 
along with advice/recommendation on the appropriate course of action.

11. Grievanc e Redressal Policy  
Soliton is committed to providing a fair, safe, and productive work environment where grievances are dealt 
sensitively and expeditiously.  
We recognize that workplace challenges may arise from time to time and have found that the best  way of 
maintaining job satisfaction and good working relationship, is to follow a procedure for solving problems 
and grievances.  
The objective of the Grievance Redressal Policy is to settle grievances of Solitons at the shortest possible 
time and to pr ovide a process so that the Soliton seeking redressal derives satisfaction.  
Scope   
A grievance may be about any act, omission, situation, or decision that a Soliton thinks is unfair, 
discriminatory, or unjustified.  
For example, We could have a grievance about:  
a) working hours or leaves   
b) work environment  
c) safety in the workplace   
d) salary levels

11. Grievanc e Redressal Policy  
e) nature of supervision   
f) performance appraisal   
g) transfer or promotion  
h) skill development or training   
i) discrimination or harassment  
The examples mentioned above are only indicative and not exhaustive.  
Disqualification:  
 All grievances re lated to sexual harassment at workplace will be covered under ‘Prevention of Sexual 
Harassment Policy’ and is excluded from the purview of this policy .

Guideline   
Formal (Open door policy)  
Solitons are free to meet any one from the leadership team including Ganesh Devaraj and Arjun 
Sathiyaseelan. But for the purpose of tracking and following it up until closure, it is recommended to route 
it through the HR Manager.  
If the Soliton is unabl e to resolve the grievance informally, he/she should raise the matter, by writing to the People 
Manager  
Then,  
A meeting will be arranged to discuss the matter with the Soliton who raised the grievance. Wherever possible, the 
meeting will be scheduled to t ake place within five working days.  
Then,  
The Soliton will receive a letter/ email confirming the outcome of the grievance meeting, normally within seven working 
days of the meeting.  
Then,  
If the individual remains dissatisfied with the outcome of the grie vance process, he/she can write to the MD who will 
review the case.  
The timelines above are intended to be used as a guideline and followed in most cases. But there may be 
times where key participants in the process are not available, for example, due  to holiday or where the 
matter is especially complex and requires detailed investigation. In such circumstances Solitons will be told 
the date by which he / she can expect a response and every effort will be made to complete the process as 
quickly as poss ible.

Confidentiality   
Solitons are free to discuss all aspects of their concerns without fear of getting judged or the information 
getting improperly disclosed. A high level of confidentiality will be maintained at all times  covering all kinds 
of information that got exchanged  in the process.  
 Each grievance may be different, raising different issues and problems. Hence  they  will be handled, in 
accordance with  the  individual circumstances.

Anonymity   
To address a grievance, it may be necessary to disclose the iden tity of the Soliton to the respondent to 
ensure adherence to the principles of fairness and natural justice. As part of the initial assessment, the HR 
manager will discuss  requests for anonymity and explore whether they are feasible.

Protection   
Solitons can be rest assured that raising any kind of grievance will not adversely affect them. All grievances 
will be handled with all possible care, sensitivity and discretion while protecting the sensibilities of the 
affected Soliton.

12. Guideline on Safe workplace for Women Solitons   
Soliton will make every possible effort to create and maintain a conducive atmosphere that ensures the 
physical, intellectual and emotional well -being of its women Solitons and provide them a safe and secure 
work environment, across all its offices.  
Towards this end, the following measures have been put in place.

Work Timing [Applicable for India Solitons]   
a) Women Soliton’s permissible work timing is till 8 pm. Work from home/connect from home can be opted 
for, to extend work beyond regular working hours, on a need basis.  
b) Email  to be sent to  HR regarding the need to extend their work time.  
c) In rare needs, i f stay in office beyond 8 pm is required, the following is mandatory,  
i. Approval - The person in need to extend work timing in office,  must receive approval from their 
Manager through email.   
ii. Travel (Drop Arrangement) - Request the HR Team through email to  arrange drop facility. This 
request has to reach by 2 pm on the day of late stay. Alternatively, if the person is able to or prefers 
to arrange safe travel by oneself, it  must be informed  to the HR team.

HR - Contact Desk   
a) Women Solitons are guaranteed  all necessary support by Management and HR.  
b) Women Solitons can report to the HR team in case if they get subject to or witness any form of unsafe 
conditions at the workplace. thepeopleteam@solitontech.com can be used but if preferred they can 
interact in person with the People team member.  
c) Clearly displayed emergency contact numbers and a designated HR representative will be available to 
be contacted in an emergency.  
d) Women Solitons are assured of complete confidentiality, s peedy redressal of their complaints and 
protection from reprisal.  
e) Additionally, feedback will be sought from female (and male) Solitons on the safety and security 
measures, from time to time and appropriate actions with respect to issues/ concerns will be  taken up 
with the highest priority.

Dos and Don’ts for Women Solitons   
Do:  
a) Stay alert and aware of the surroundings within and outside the office premises.  
b) Familiarize ourself with the company guidelines on overall safety and security at the w orkplace.  
c) Avail the option of working/ connecting from home if we have to extend our work beyond regular working 
hours.  
d) Report unsafe conditions and all instances of discrimination, to the Manager or HR, without fear and 
also encourage/ support fellow co lleagues to do the same.   
 e) Keep emergency contact numbers, Police help -line numbers and details of company contact points 
handy at all times.  
Do not:  
a) Venture out alone to dimly -lit areas/ staircases/ parking lots, in and around the office premises, Hire cabs/ 
transport vehicles from lesser known cab  services/  agencies,  while travelling to and from work.

13.  Policy for Prevention of Sexual Harassment at Workplace (POSH)  
 Soliton Technologies (hereinafter “the Company”) is c ommitted to creating and maintaining a secure work 
environment where all Solitons, vendors and partners can work and pursue business together in an 
atmosphere free of exploitation and intimidation caused by acts of sexual harassment, within but not limited  
to, the office premises and other locations directly related to the company’s business. Soliton firmly believes 
that all Solitons should be treated with dignity and respect and expects everyone to promote a sense of 
personal responsibility.  
This Policy  has been framed in accordance with the provisions of “The Sexual Harassment of Women at 
Workplace (Prevention, Prohibition and Redressal) Act, 2013” and rules framed thereunder (hereinafter “the 
Act”). Accordingly, while the Policy covers all the key aspe cts of the Act, for any further clarification reference 
shall always be made to the Act and the provisions of the Act shall prevail.  
The objective of this Policy is to provide protection against sexual harassment at the workplace and the 
prevention and redressal of complaints of sexual harassment and matters related to it.  
Scope   
This policy applies to all Solitons (full -time, part -time, interns, trainees, and those on contractual 
assignments) of the Company including all subsidiaries and affiliated companies, at their workplace or at 
client sites. The company will not tolerate sex ual harassment, if engaged in by clients, suppliers, or any 
other business associates.

1.  Definition What is Sexual Harassment?  
Sexual harassment includes any one or more of the following unwelcome acts or behavior (whether directly 
or by implic ation):  
a) Any unwelcome sexually determined behavior, or pattern of conduct, that would cause discomfort and/ 
or humiliate a person at whom the behavior or conduct was directed namely:   
i.Physical contact and advances.  
ii.Demand or request for sexual  favors. iii.Sexually colored remarks or remarks of a sexual 
nature about a person's clothing or body.  
iv.Showing pornography, making or posting sexual pranks, sexual teasing, sexual jokes, sexually 
demeaning or offensive pictures, cartoons or other mater ials through email, SMS, MMS, Whatsapp, 
social media, etc.   
 v.Repeatedly asking to socialize during off -duty hours or continued expressions of sexual interest 
against a person’s wishes. Giving gifts or leaving objects that are sexually suggestive.  
vi.Eve teasing, innuendos and taunts, physical confinement against one’s will or any such act likely 
to intrude upon one’s privacy. Persistent watching, following, contacting of a person.  
vii.Any other unwelcome physical, verbal, or non -verbal conduct of sexual nature.

1.  Definition What is Sexual Harassment?  
b) The following circumstances if it occurs, or is present, in relation to any sexually determined act or 
behavior amount to sexual harassment:  
i. Implied or explicit promise of preferential treatment in employment  ii. 
Implied or explic it threat of detrimental treatment in employment iii. 
Implied or explicit threat about the present or future employment status  
iv. Interference with the person’s work or creating an intimidating or offensive or hostile work 
environment  
v. Humiliating treatment likely to affect health or safety  
It is important to note that whether harassment has occurred or not does not depend on the intention of 
people but on the experience of the aggrieved woman.

2. Aggrieved woman  
In relation to a workplace, a wom an, of any age, whether employed or not, who alleges to have been 
subjected to any act of sexual harassment and includes people on contract and temporary visitors.

3. Respondent  
A person against whom a complaint of sexual harassment has been made by an aggrieved Woman. In the 
event that the respondent is not a Soliton of the Company, the POSH Committee shall, as and when the 
need arises, device the process to conduct enquiries and  to assist the complainant to file the complaint 
before the right redressal forum.

4. Complainant  
A complaint may be filed on behalf of the aggrieved woman if the woman is incapacitated. Such complaint 
maybe filed by a relative, friend, colleague , or any person with the knowledge of the incident, provided such 
person has knowledge of the incident.

5. Workplace   
• All offices or other premises where the Company’s business is conducted  
• All company -related activities performed at any other site away from the Company’s premises.  
• Any social, business, or other functions where the conduct or comments may have an adverse 
impact on the workplace or workplace relations.  
• Any place where the ag grieved woman or the respondent visits in connection with his/ her work, 
during the course of and/ or arising out of employment/ contract/ engagement with the Company, 
including transportation provided for undertaking such a journey.

6. Employer   
A person responsible for management, supervision, and control of the workplace at the Company.

Roles and Responsibilities   
a) Responsibilities of individuals: It is the responsibility of all Solitons to respect the rights of others and to 
never  encourage harassment. It can be done by:  
i.  Refusing to participate in any activity which constitutes harassment  
ii. Supporting the person to reject unwelcome behavior   
iii. Acting as a witness, if the person being harassed decides to lodge a complai nt  
All Solitons are encouraged to advise one another of behavior that is unwelcome. Often, some 
behaviors are not intentional; while this does not make it acceptable, it does give the person 
behaving inappropriately, the opportunity to modify or stop th eir offensive behavior.  
b) Responsibilities of Supervisors: All Solitons in supervisory roles (SPEs, PLs, PMs, Team Managers, BU 
Managers, etc.) must ensure that all Solitons in their teams understand that harassment will not be 
tolerated and that complain ts will be taken seriously.

Complaints Redressal Mechanism   
In compliance with the Act, for the complaint to warrant formal intervention, the complainant needs to lodge 
a written complaint, which shall be followed by a formal redressal mechanism as described in this Policy. In 
case of a verbal complaint, the compla int will be recorded in writing by the receiver of the complaint and 
signatures of the complainant will be obtained.

a. Internal Complaints Committee (hereinafter “ICC”)  
The responsibility for administering this Policy rests with the Internal Compl aints Committee (hereinafter 
“ICC”) as required under the Act. ICC is constituted in order to prevent instances of sexual harassment and 
to receive and effectively deal with complaints pertaining to the same. The ICC comprises:  
i. Presiding Officer: A S enior woman Soliton of the company ii. Two members from Human Resources/ 
People Operations department  iii. One external member from an NGO or an advocate. iii. Employer: A 
person responsible for management, supervision, and control of the workplace at the  Company.  
The ICC is responsible for:  
a) Investigating every formal written complaint of sexual harassment  
b) Taking appropriate remedial measures to respond to any substantiated allegations of sexual 
harassment  
c) Submitting findings and recommendations of inquiries to designated authorities  
d) Coordinating with the employer in implementing appropriate action  
e) Maintaining strict confidentiality throughout the process as per established guidelines  
f) Submitting annual re ports in the prescribed format to designated authorities  
g) Discouraging and preventing employment -related sexual harassment

b. Lodging a complaint   
A complainant/ aggrieved woman can file a complaint with the ICC within a period a 3 months from the date 
of the incident and in case of a series of incidents within 3 months from the date of last incident. The ICC  
 may extend the time limit of 3 months if it is satisfied with the reasons of the delay in filing the complaint; 
the reasons for delay needs to be submitted in writing to the ICC.  
A written complaint providing the name, department and details of the incident may be sent via email to 
POSH@solito ntech.com. The recipient of this email would be the presiding officer of ICC and all emails 
sent to this ID will be treated with utmost confidentiality.

c. Conducting the inquiry  
The ICC may, before initiating an inquiry and at the request of the a ggrieved woman, take steps to settle 
the matter between her and the respondent through conciliation as stated under Section 10 of the Act. 
However, no monetary settlement shall be made as a basis of such conciliation. It is also made clear to all 
parties t hat conciliation in itself doesn’t necessarily mean acceptance of complaint by the respondent. It is 
a practical mechanism through which issues are resolved or misunderstandings cleared.  
In case a settlement is arrived at, the ICC records & reports the same to the employer for taking appropriate 
action. Resolution through conciliation happens within 2 weeks of receipt of complaint. The ICC provides 
copies of the settlement to complainant & respondent. Once the action is implemented, no further inquiry is  
conducted.  
The ICC initiates inquiry in the following cases:  
a) No conciliation is requested by aggrieved woman  
b) Conciliation has not resulted in any settlement  
c) Complainant informs the ICC that any terms or conditions of the settlement arrived through  
conciliation, has not been complied with, by the respondent(s)  
The ICC proceeds to make an inquiry into the complaint within a period of 1 week of its receipt of the original 
complaint/ closure of conciliation/ repeat complaint.

Manner of inquiry into complaint  
a) Complainant should submit the complaint along with supporting documents and the names of the 
witnesses  
b) Upon receipt of the complaint, the ICC sends 1 copy of the complaint to respondent within 7 working 
days  
c) Respondent replies with all supporting documents within 10 working days of receiving the copy of the 
complaint  
d) No legal practitioner can represent an y party at any stage of the inquiry procedure  
e) The ICC makes inquiry into the complaint in accordance with the principles of natural justice  
f) In conducting the inquiry, a minimum of three ICC members including the Presiding Officer is present  
During pen dency of the inquiry, on a written request made by the complainant, the ICC may recommend to 
the employer to -  
a) Transfer the complainant or the respondent to any other workplace  
b) Grant leave to the aggrieved woman of maximum 3 months, in addition to the leave she would otherwise 
be entitled  
c) Prevent the respondent from assessing complainant’s work performance  
d) Grant such other relief as may be appropriate

Termination of Inquiry  
 ICC may terminate the inquiry or give ex -parte decision, if complainan t or respondent respectively is absent 
for 3 consecutive hearings, without reason. 15 day written notice to be given to the party, before termination 
or ex -parte order.

Inquiry procedure  
All proceedings of the inquiry is documented. ICC interviews the respondent separately and impartially.  
a) ICC states exactly what the allegation is and who has made the allegation. The respondent is given 
full opportunity to respond and provide any eviden ce etc.  
b) Detailed notes of the meetings are prepared which may be shared with the respondent and 
complainant upon request.  
c) Any witnesses produced by the respondent are also interviewed & statements are taken.  
d) In case complainant or respondent seeks to as k questions to the other party, they may give them 
to ICC, which asks them and records the statement of the other party.  
e) Any such inquiry is completed, including the submission of the inquiry report, within 90 days from 
the date on which the inquiry is co mmenced.  
f) The inquiry procedure ensures absolute fairness to all parties.  
g) A copy of the proceedings were made available to both parties enabling them to make 
representation against the findings.

Complaint unsubstantiated  
Where ICC arrives at the c onclusion that the allegation against the respondent has not been proven, it 
recommends to the employer that no action is required to be taken in this matter.  
Further, ICC ensures that both parties understand that the matter has been fully investigated,  that the matter 
is now concluded, and neither will be disadvantaged within the company.

Complaint substantiated  
Where ICC arrives at the conclusion that the allegation against the respondent has been proven, it 
recommends to the employer, to take necessary action, in accordance with the applicable service rules and 
policies, and this may include:  
a) Counseling  
b) Censure or reprimand  
c) Apology to be tendered by respondent  
d) Written warning  
e) Withholding promotion and/ or increments  
f) Suspension  
g) Termination  
h) Or any other action that the employer and the Company management may deem fit  
The employer acts upon the recommendations within 60 days and confirms to the ICC.  
Post implementation of  the actions follow up with the aggrieved woman/ complainant occurs to ascertain 
whether the behavior has in fact stopped, the solution is working satisfactorily, and that no victimization of 
either party has occurred. This follow up is undertaken by the c omplainant/ aggrieved woman’s supervisor, 
supported by HR.

Malicious Allegations  
 Where ICC arrives at the conclusion that the allegation against the respondent is malicious or the aggrieved 
woman or the complainant has made the complaint knowing it  to be false or has forged or produced 
misleading document, it may recommend to the employer to take action against the aggrieved woman or 
the complainant.

Confidentiality  
Notwithstanding anything contained in the Right to Information Act, 2005, th e contents of the complaint 
made, the identity and addresses of the aggrieved woman, respondent and witnesses, any information 
relating to conciliation and inquiry proceedings, recommendations of the ICC etc. shall not be published, 
communicated, or made k nown to the public, press and media in any manner.

Appeal  
Any party not satisfied or further aggrieved by the implementation or non -implementation of 
recommendations made, may appeal to the appellate authority in accordance with the Act and rule s, within 
90 days of the recommendations being communicated.

Guidelines for members of the Internal Complaints Committee   
a) Believe in the reality of the complaint lodged.  
b) Empathize with the complainant. Do not function like a criminal court.  
c) Remember that it may be difficult for an Soliton to talk about anything ‘sexual’. Hence there can be 
a long time interval between the harassment and the actual complaint.  
d) Handle compl aints in a confidential manner and within the stipulated time period.  
e) Submit annual report on sexual harassment cases, if any, and actions taken to address the same, 
to the CEO, Head of Human Resources and/ or designated authority.  
f) Maintain all the data related to sexual harassment cases in the company. Document results of any 
sexual harassment complaint or investigation. Not only the results, but also document any 
corrective action that the Soliton or supervisor was asked to take.  
g) Provide safety for the  complainant and his / her supporters, if such a need be felt and that the ICC 
can recommend action against persons indulging in intimidation of the complainant or witness to a 
complaint.  
h) Discard predetermined notions of how an accused should look or beha ve or dress. Be aware of 
stereotypes.

Guidelines for members of the Internal Complaints Committee   
i) Do not insist on detailed description of harassment. This could increase the aggrieved woman/ 
complainant’s trauma.  
j) Most sexual crimes are committed in private; hence there may not be any eyewitnesses. Since this 
is a human rights issue, balance of probabilities is a sufficient measure of proof.  
k) Help the complainant regain his / her self -respect.    
l) Make ‘discreet’ enquiries as to whether other Solitons have experienced similar problems.  
m) Inform all Solitons that it is their obligation to report sexual harassment that they either experience 
or witness.  
n) The inability to substantiate a complaint or provide adequate proof need not attract action against 
the aggrieved woman/ complainant.
